column1:
The caching is only necessary for the performance benefit of not needing to do that service query from the DB every time we get an instance, which doubles the traffic to the DB on every instance query, which kind of sucks.
 
 Agree with leaving the caching in, that was my point with removing the TODO so we don't forget about this.
column2:
The caching is necessary to enhance performance by avoiding the need for a service query from the database each time we request an instance. Without caching, the traffic to the database doubles with every instance query, which is quite inconvenient.

I agree with keeping the caching functionality intact. That was the intention behind removing the TODO, so we don't forget about it.

column1: you can. some people prefer reinterpret_cast because it shouts "danger! crappy type-unsafe C API here!". others prefer static_cast because it's the weakest cast that will still work. i'll +2 either (but tend to use reinterpret_cast personally; i've never seen anyone make the mistakes that static_cast would prevent in this specific circumstance).
column2: You can use either. Some people prefer reinterpret_cast because it emphasizes the risks associated with type-unsafe C API. Others opt for static_cast because it provides the minimum level of casting required. I would approve either option (although I personally lean towards reinterpret_cast

column1:
hmmmm...that is a good reason to keep mountpoint around. Which kind of sucks. Also, mountpoint is optional from Nova's standpoint, so we probably shouldn't just raise and fail, unless it's a multi-attach to the same instance (the knucklehead case), which means more checks for that case.
 I vote we just dis-allow that...
column2: Well, that's a good reason to retain mountpoint. Unfortunately, it's not ideal. Additionally, from Nova's perspective, mountpoint is optional, so we shouldn't raise an error unless it's a multi-attach to the same instance (an exceptional case), which would require additional checks. I suggest disallowing that scenario altogether.

column1: I disagree. In this instance it is an instance that we have partially created, and that the user has no knowledge of its existence. We should not leave half created turds lying around. However, you have drawn attention to that fact that we are eating an exception, which we should not be doing.
column2: I have a different perspective on this matter. In this particular case, we're dealing with a partially created instance that the user is unaware of. Leaving incomplete artifacts behind is not desirable. However, you've highlighted the fact that we're suppressing an exception, which we should avoid.

column1:
scope_logger.cc doesn't exist in libshill-net users, like apmanager.
 
 Do we move it under common/ and make apmanager depend on a separate shared library, just for that tiny shill-specific piece of code?
 
 Do we move it under net/ where it doesn't really belong?
 
 Do we tell library callers to implement the ScopeLogger class just so that libshill-net links? That's kind of an ugly interface for a library; at least for C-based shared libraries it is generally nicer to ask users to register a callback than for the .so file to try to link against some of the main executable's symbols.
column2:
The file scope_logger.cc doesn't exist in libshill-net users like apmanager.
Should we consider moving it under common/ and making apmanager dependent on a separate shared library just for that small shill-specific code?

Should we relocate it under net/ even though it doesn't truly belong there?

Should we instruct library callers to implement the ScopeLogger class just for the sake of linking libshill-net? It's not an elegant interface for a library; typically, for C-based shared libraries, it's preferable to ask users to register a callback rather than having the .so file link against symbols from the main executable.

column1:
Yes, but I guess this is rabbit issue only, due to the fact that the reply queue have been historically created with auto_delete=True.
 
 Another rabbitmq reported issue in the past was that a HA rabbitmq cluster that failover can in certain circumstance report that the queue doesn't exists just after the failover when It exists in reality. That another reason of why we do this crap.
column2:
Yes, but I believe this is a specific issue with RabbitMQ due to the historical creation of the reply queue with auto_delete=True.
Another reported RabbitMQ issue in the past was that during failover in a highly available RabbitMQ cluster, the queue can sometimes be reported as non-existent immediately after failover, even though it actually exists. That's another reason why we're dealing with this situation.

column1:
This is what the query looks like:
 
 SELECT ports.tenant_id AS ports_tenant_id, ports.id AS ports_id, ports.name AS ports_name, ports.network_id AS ports_network_id, ports.mac_address AS ports_mac_address, ports.admin_state_up AS ports_admin_state_up, ports.status AS ports_status, ports.device_id AS ports_device_id, ports.device_owner AS ports_device_owner, securitygroupportbindings.security_group_id AS securitygroupportbindings_security_group_id, ipallocations_1.port_id AS ipallocations_1_port_id, ipallocations_1.ip_address AS ipallocations_1_ip_address, ipallocations_1.subnet_id AS ipallocations_1_subnet_id, ipallocations_1.network_id AS ipallocations_1_network_id, allowedaddresspairs_1.port_id AS allowedaddresspairs_1_port_id, allowedaddresspairs_1.mac_address AS allowedaddresspairs_1_mac_address, allowedaddresspairs_1.ip_address AS allowedaddresspairs_1_ip_address, ml2_port_bindings_1.port_id AS ml2_port_bindings_1_port_id, ml2_port_bindings_1.host AS ml2_port_bindings_1_host, ml2_port_bindings_1.vnic_type AS ml2_port_bindings_1_vnic_type, ml2_port_bindings_1.profile AS ml2_port_bindings_1_profile, ml2_port_bindings_1.vif_type AS ml2_port_bindings_1_vif_type, ml2_port_bindings_1.vif_details AS ml2_port_bindings_1_vif_details, ml2_port_bindings_1.driver AS ml2_port_bindings_1_driver, ml2_port_bindings_1.segment AS ml2_port_bindings_1_segment, securitygroupportbindings_1.port_id AS securitygroupportbindings_1_port_id, securitygroupportbindings_1.security_group_id AS securitygroupportbindings_1_security_group_id, extradhcpopts_1.id AS extradhcpopts_1_id, extradhcpopts_1.port_id AS extradhcpopts_1_port_id, extradhcpopts_1.opt_name AS extradhcpopts_1_opt_name, extradhcpopts_1.opt_value AS extradhcpopts_1_opt_value, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.port_id AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_port_id, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.host AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_host, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.router_id AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_router_id, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.vif_type AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_vif_type, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.vif_details AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_vif_details, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.vnic_type AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_vnic_type, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.profile AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_profile, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.cap_port_filter AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_cap_port_filter, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.driver AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_driver, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.segment AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_segment, ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.status AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_status 
 FROM ports LEFT OUTER JOIN securitygroupportbindings ON ports.id = securitygroupportbindings.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN ipallocations AS ipallocations_1 ON ports.id = ipallocations_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN allowedaddresspairs AS allowedaddresspairs_1 ON ports.id = allowedaddresspairs_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN ml2_port_bindings AS ml2_port_bindings_1 ON ports.id = ml2_port_bindings_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN securitygroupportbindings AS securitygroupportbindings_1 ON ports.id = securitygroupportbindings_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN extradhcpopts AS extradhcpopts_1 ON ports.id = extradhcpopts_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN ml2_dvr_port_bindings AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1 ON ports.id = ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.port_id 
 WHERE ports.id IN (:id_1, :id_2, :id_3, :id_4, :id_5, :id_6)
 
 Maybe we want to disable eager loading so it doesn't pull in all that crap we don't need? We really only want the port and security groups?

ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.status AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1_status 
 FROM ports LEFT OUTER JOIN securitygroupportbindings ON ports.id = securitygroupportbindings.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN ipallocations AS ipallocations_1 ON ports.id = ipallocations_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN allowedaddresspairs AS allowedaddresspairs_1 ON ports.id = allowedaddresspairs_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN ml2_port_bindings AS ml2_port_bindings_1 ON ports.id = ml2_port_bindings_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN securitygroupportbindings AS securitygroupportbindings_1 ON ports.id = securitygroupportbindings_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN extradhcpopts AS extradhcpopts_1 ON ports.id = extradhcpopts_1.port_id LEFT OUTER JOIN ml2_dvr_port_bindings AS ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1 ON ports.id = ml2_dvr_port_bindings_1.port_id 
 WHERE ports.id IN (:id_1, :id_2, :id_3, :id_4, :id_5, :id_6)

Perhaps we should consider disabling eager loading to retrieve only the necessary information, such as ports and security groups.

column1:
Yes, unfortunately this does add some fragility here. Though you are wrong that it is inserting namespace data. And of course if the compiler does add that, it would make for a 100% failure rate of the test (fun fact: __func__ apparently at least on the Android build system is resolved to __PRETTY_FUNCTION__ which does add a lot of crap).

As per the commend on the hardcoded strings though, this way we are ensuring we have to correct mapping and don't require constants for everything that is redundant and makes it harder to add tests.

Again, this is a test - not another abstraction layer on top of a HAL on top of an API...
column2:
Although there is a risk of fragility here, you're mistaken about the insertion of namespace data. In any case, by using hardcoded strings, we ensure the correct mapping and avoid the need for redundant constants that complicate the addition of tests.

Remember, this is a test and not an additional abstraction layer on top of a HAL and API.

column1:
One way to make exploitation harder even if there's no guard page would be to add weak secondary stack ASLR in Bionic. The problem with that is it can screw over callers with very precisely sized stacks, as they'll have less available than they expect.

Using a single page for ASLR with stacks >= 1M is arguably sane because they could be screwed over by a compiler update if they're that close to the end...

I have a patch doing this but it's pretty sketchy so I didn't have plans to upstream it.
column2:
One approach to make exploitation more difficult, even without a guard page, would be to implement weak secondary stack ASLR in Bionic. However, this could potentially cause issues for callers with precisely sized stacks, as they would have less available than expected.

Using a single page for ASLR with stacks larger than or equal to 1M could be considered reasonable, given the potential impact of a compiler update if the stack is near its end.

I have a patch addressing this, but it's somewhat experimental, so I hadn't planned on submitting it upstream.

column1:
This part is apparently not true. (if by upper layers, you mean other parts of flashrom.)

I tried 'flashrom --read /tmp/c.bin' on Kevin, and this produced a large (full 8MB I think?) read, which apparently the SPI driver still can't handle. I need to fix that up...

But this means unfortunately, we should keep the hack for now, and loop over eraseblock sized chunks in the 'read' path still. And for your sake, we can do the same for writes. (I just objected to changing the "page size".)

Sorry for jerking you around a bit :) I'll try to fix things up on the MTD side a bit, so we don't have to live with these hacks forever.
column2:
It appears that this part is incorrect (if by "upper layers" you mean other sections of flashrom).

I tested 'flashrom --read /tmp/c.bin' on Kevin, which resulted in a large read (probably the entire 8MB), indicating that the SPI driver still can't handle it. I need to address that issue...

Unfortunately, this means we should retain the workaround for now and iterate over eraseblock-sized chunks in the 'read' path. And to ensure consistency, we can apply the same approach for writes (I just disagreed with changing the "page size").

Apologies for the confusion earlier. I'll strive to improve things on the MTD side so we won't have to rely on these workarounds indefinitely.

column1:
doesn't this just mean we fucked up the mips syscall.S in bionic? the other architectures move the syscall number into the appropriate register and then make that system call directly. on mips, we actually use a 'syscall' system call. i don't think that's necessary, and we should just fix the mips syscall.S in bionic.

(is __NR_syscall even implemented? i can't find it in the kernel source.)
column2:
Does this mean that we made an error in the mips syscall.S file in bionic? Other architectures move the syscall number into the appropriate register and then make the system call directly, but on mips, we use a 'syscall' system call. I don't believe it's necessary, and we should fix the mips syscall.S file in bionic.

(Is __NR_syscall even implemented? I couldn't find it in the kernel source.)

column1:
That is a good point. Arguably, Minijail does allow you to fuck some things up (but not many) -- you can always pass a full capabilities mask for example.

If you want to draft a version of this CL that delays the ELF linkage check, that's fine. If you want to land this to unblock other work, that's OK.
column2: That's a valid observation. With Minijail, there is some possibility of making mistakes (though limited). For instance, one can unintentionally pass a full capabilities mask. If you prefer, you can prepare a version of this CL that postpones the ELF linkage check. Alternatively, if you need to proceed with this to unblock other work, that's also acceptable.

column1:
Because the : operator is dumb, it doesn't take nullopt here, and
  kerberos_files_handler_.SetFiles(
      response.files().has_krb5cc() ? response.files().krb5cc()
                                    : base::Optional<std::string>(),
      response.files().has_krb5conf() ? response.files().krb5conf()
                                      : base::Optional<std::string>());
is one line longer and less readable.
column2:
Due to the limitations of the ":" operator, it doesn't accept nullopt in this case. As a result, the code becomes longer and less readable:


kerberos_files_handler_.SetFiles(
    response.files().has_krb5cc() ? response.files().krb5cc()
                                  : base::Optional<std::string>(),
    response.files().has_krb5conf() ? response.files().krb5conf()
                                    : base::Optional<std::string>());

column1:
2 things:
 
 1) Is it possible to UNPAUSE a machine which is RUNNING!? (I would think that you can only UNPAUSE something that is PAUSED, hidden bug? Why UNPAUSING is being saved to the db if the current state is RUNNING?)
 
 2) I think that for [UN]PAUSING we should take a different approach than this.
 
 At this point, the real state of the instance is unknown right? We don't know whether the instance was paused or not, but, we already know the desired state and the current state why we just don't automate that?
 
 If before n-cpu crashed the user requested to pause that instance and I assume that the API have returned saying that the requested was accept, why we don't re-issue the [un]pause_instance() request here?
 
 I mean users would be like: "fuck yeah automation"!
 
 Instead of just cleaning up the states, leaving the machine in an unknown state and having the user to reissue the request to [un]pause the machine again.
 
 (And sorry if someone already suggested that, I haven't looked in all previous patch-sets to see if that's the case)
column2:
Two points to consider:
Is it possible to unpause a machine that is currently running? I always thought you could only unpause something that is currently paused. Is there a hidden bug here? Also, why is the action of unpausing being saved to the database if the current state is already running?

I think we should explore a different approach for pausing and unpausing. Currently, the real state of the instance is unknown, right? We don't know whether the instance was paused or not, but we already have the desired state and the current state. Why don't we automate the process based on that information?

For example, if before the n-cpu crashed, the user requested to pause that instance and the API confirmed the request, shouldn't we re-issue the unpause_instance() request here? Users would probably appreciate the automation instead of having to manually reissue the request to unpause the machine, leaving it in an unknown state. (I apologize if someone already suggested this; I haven't reviewed all the previous patch-sets to confirm.)

column1:
Shameless aping of how eventlet does things. eventlet.greenpool.GreenPile does the same thing.
 
 It is rather convenient, though. If you just want to run N tasks in M threads, make a Green[Async]Pile(M). If you want to share a pool with other tasks or have wacky requirements for your pool (like ContextPool), keep a pool around and make a Green[Async]Pile(pool).
column2: This approach is an explicit copycat of how eventlet does things. In eventlet.greenpool, the GreenPile class also follows the same pattern. However, it does offer convenience. If you only want to run N tasks in M threads, you can create a Green[Async]Pile(M). If you have specific requirements or want to share a pool with other tasks (like ContextPool), you can keep a pool and create a Green[Async]Pile(pool) instance.

column1:
The thing different about storm is its ro image size - it is well in excess of 2MB due to all the SBL/RPM/TZBSP crap.

The existing code also was a hack added earlier (see https://gerrit.chromium.org/gerrit/43380 for the description), it  relied on the assumption that the ro coreboot always fits into 1 MB starting from the top of the blob. 

This assumption is true for Nyan (and all other targets so far), but not for Storm.
column2: One notable difference with Storm is its larger read-only (ro) image size, exceeding 2MB due to the inclusion of SBL/RPM/TZBSP components. Additionally, the existing code was a previous workaround added (refer to https://gerrit.chromium.org/gerrit/43380 for the description). It relied on the assumption that the ro coreboot always fits within 1MB from the top of the blob. This assumption holds true for Nyan (and all other targets so far), but not for Storm.

column1:
This maybe a dumb question. "_" is used to say "please ignore", but gettext() also defines _(). Do they conflict? i.e. if we are using gettext can we use _ to ignore variables too or will it overwrite the definition of _()?
 
  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3967231/whats-the-meaning-of-in-python
 
  Just some playing around:
  >>> import gettext
  >>> gettext.install('angus') 
  >>> print _('hello')
  hello 
  >>> 5
  5 
  >>> print _
  5
  >>> print _('hello')
  Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: 'int' object is not callable
  >>>
 
  WTF!?
column2: This might be a naive question, but "" is commonly used to signify "please ignore," yet gettext() also defines "()". Do they conflict with each other? In other words, if we're using gettext, can we still use "" to ignore variables, or will it overwrite the definition of "()"?

column1:
Oh dear, I didn't realize this workflow description was so far off. Darn you, diff-based-reviews! You're failing me!
 
 So, added to the above workflow should be:
 * Create a LoadBalancer object
 * Create a Listener
 * Associate the Listener with the LoadBalancer
 * Associate the Pool with the Listener.
 
 And optionally:
 * If HTTPS termination is being utilized, you must also:
 ** Add the TLS certificate, key, and optional chain to Barbican
 ** Associate the Barbican container with the Listener
 
 * If Layer-7 HTTP switching is being used you must also:
 * Create any additional pools, members, and healthmonitors which will be used as non-default pools.
 * Create a Layer-7 policy associating the Listener with the non-default Pool
 * Create rules for the Layer-7 policy which describe the logic behind selecting the non-default pool for servicing some requests.
column2:
I didn't realize that the workflow description was so far off. Diff-based reviews really let me down! To rectify this, let's add the following steps to the above workflow:
Create a LoadBalancer object
Create a Listener
Associate the Listener with the LoadBalancer
Associate the Pool with the Listener
Optionally, if HTTPS termination is used, we must also:
Add the TLS certificate, key, and optional chain to Barbican
Associate the Barbican container with the Listener
If Layer-7 HTTP switching is utilized, we must also:
Create any additional pools, members, and healthmonitors for non-default pools
Create a Layer-7 policy that associates the Listener with the non-default Pool
Define rules for the Layer-7 policy that specify the logic behind selecting the non-default pool for servicing specific requests.

column1:
`atest host mod` supports a -a option for specifying attributes
as "key=value".  For consistency, this command should have its
own option for specifying attributes as "key=value" pairs, too.
I'd say this command should use -a, too, but it's already taken.

Really, 'create' and 'mod' should support the same options.
Unfortunately, <rant>WE'RE STUPID, AND WE LET THE
COMMANDS DIVERGE</rant>.  Still, we should find some way
to specify attributes as "key=value", rather than adding individual
options for each attribute.  It will help keep the stupidity from
spreading.
column2: The atest host mod command supports a -a option for specifying attributes as "key=value". For consistency, this command should have its own option for specifying attributes in the same way. Although we can't use -a due to conflicts, we should find a way to specify attributes as "key=value" pairs instead of adding individual options for each attribute. This will prevent the situation from becoming more complicated.

The 'newapi' package name sucks a bit.
 Mostly because at some point it would not be new anymore.

column2:
The 'newapi' package name doesn't seem quite right, mainly because it won't be new forever. Additionally, we're not defining a new API; we're actually changing the WSGI framework. Perhaps we should consider a different name. When I was experimenting with it about a year ago, I created a neutron.pecan_wsgi package.
Anyway, enough nitpicking for now. If we change the name at this point, we'll have to update and rebase all the patches. Let's stick with 'newapi' for now, but let's change it before merging the branch back in.

column1:
Except for 'bvt', most pools for most boards are empty. The
 `get_managed_boards()` call here will return all the boards,
 which means the board+pool combinations enumerated
 below will include many entries with no DUTs, meaning we'll
 be adding lots of no-op balancing operations.
 
 I'm not sure that this is expensive, but it seems awkward.
 
 A fix would be to provide an optional pool parameter to
 `get_managed_boards()` to restrict the select to a given pool.
column2: With the exception of 'bvt', most pools for most boards are empty. The get_managed_boards() call will return all the boards, resulting in numerous entries with no DUTs in the enumerated board+pool combinations. As a result, we'll end up performing many unnecessary balancing operations. Although I'm uncertain about the performance impact, the current approach seems awkward. A potential solution would be to introduce an optional pool parameter to get_managed_boards() to restrict the selection to a specific pool.

column1: It would be nice to offer 2 (at least)  redis and sqlalchemy. IMHO this forces us to create API's that work against more than one implementation (which makes the API's better) and it avoids pitfalls later when we say oh crap a sqlalchemy implementation isn't the only way to do this (and then we are stuck in a corner because we made API's that are specific to sqlalchemy).
column2: It would be beneficial to support at least two implementations, such as Redis and SQLAlchemy. In my opinion, this approach encourages the development of APIs that work with multiple implementations, resulting in more robust APIs. Additionally, it helps avoid future pitfalls if we realize that SQLAlchemy is not the only suitable option and need to make changes.

column1:
Er, to clarify: with or without this change, SSL_renegotiate in BoringSSL always failed. BoringSSL can't initiate renego, only accept it as a client.

Which means this line isn't reachable in BoringSSL ports, so it doesn't actually matter that SSL_set_state is, strictly speaking, a no-op in BoringSSL. (Reaching into the SSL* and messing with its state machine is kind of insane. OpenSSL's renego API is terrible.)

Given that, I'm not sure what the test is doing when compiled against BoringSSL since it apparently doesn't notice. But this change shouldn't make things worse.
column2:
To clarify, with or without this change, SSL_renegotiate in BoringSSL always failed. BoringSSL can only accept renegotiation as a client; it can't initiate it. Therefore, this line is unreachable in BoringSSL ports, so it doesn't really matter that SSL_set_state is technically a no-op in BoringSSL. (Accessing SSL* and manipulating its state machine is quite complex. OpenSSL's renegotiation API is not ideal.)

Considering this, I'm not sure what the test is doing when compiled against BoringSSL since it doesn't seem to cause any issues. However, this change shouldn't make things worse.

column1:
I'd rather see this check in hsi2c_write() and hsi2c_read() so they can do something sensible with it.  It seems like they'd need to be cognizant of it.  For a write of 0 bytes, won't you end up with a timeout?

Kinda sucks that it doesn't support len of 0.  :(  I suppose worst case we could switch to manual mode for this, but not worth doing now.
column2: I'd rather see this check implemented in hsi2c_write() and hsi2c_read() so that they can handle it appropriately. They need to be aware of this situation. For a write operation of 0 bytes, we might encounter a timeout. It's disappointing that it doesn't support a length of 0. Worst case, we could switch to manual mode for this, but it's not worth pursuing at the moment.

column1:
The thing different about storm is its ro image size - it is well in excess of 2MB due to all the SBL/RPM/TZBSP crap.
 
 The existing code also was a hack added earlier (see https://gerrit.chromium.org/gerrit/43380 for the description), it relied on the assumption that the ro coreboot always fits into 1 MB starting from the top of the blob. 
 
 This assumption is true for Nyan (and all other targets so far), but not for Storm.
column2: The unique aspect of Storm is its read-only image size, which exceeds 2MB due to SBL/RPM/TZBSP components. The existing code was initially added as a workaround (refer to https://gerrit.chromium.org/gerrit/43380 for the description). It relied on the assumption that the ro coreboot always fits within 1MB from the top of the blob. While this assumption holds true for Nyan and other targets, it's not the case for Storm.

column1:
For git commit messages, try to keep the first line self-contained and within 72 characters.

Lots of things will show just the first line, so its useful to have it be a brief summary.

(Some sadistic jerks try to impose an even tighter limit like 65 characters, but I think thats ludicrous.)

A message like this would do:

minidump: Allow for user extension streams computed at crash time

(hey, 65 exactly!)
column2:
When writing Git commit messages, it's advisable to keep the first line self-contained and within 72 characters. Many tools and displays only show the first line, so it's beneficial to have a concise summary. While some individuals insist on an even stricter limit like 65 characters, I personally find that impractical. A message like this would work:

minidump: Allow user extension streams to be computed at crash time

(Exactly 65 characters!)

It shouldn't cause any issues, but it's a precautionary measure.

column1: i think the problem was that Daemons.stop stops the threads we *deliberately* started. if some code had started other threads, you got very hard to debug situations. so we added this extra method so you'd have a nice clear hang to debug if you'd screwed up.
column2: This is really messy. The issue lies in the fact that Daemons.stop stops all threads, even those intentionally started. If any code had initiated additional threads, it would lead to challenging debugging scenarios. To address this, we introduced an extra method to explicitly handle the situation and provide a clear indication of a hang for more straightforward debugging.

column1:
1) emerge -C mali-drivers-bin doesn't suffice?

2) Clarify this please; each time there is a new version of the blobs, this ebuild should be getting a bump.  That bump means the old version is replaced w/ the new.  Basically, the package manager should be handling that crap- unless the concern is how your shar bits (which vapier is trying to kill off in favor of ACCEPT_LICENSE- something I agree with as long as the ToS allows for this) deal w/ the implicit orphaning of the libmali dso...
column2:
Would "emerge -C mali-drivers-bin" not suffice?

Could you please provide some clarification? Each time a new version of the blobs is released, this ebuild should be updated accordingly. The update would involve replacing the old version with the new one. Generally, the package manager should handle such matters, unless there are concerns about how your shar bits (which vapier is trying to eliminate in favor of ACCEPT_LICENSE, a move I support if the Terms of Service permit) handle the implicit orphaning of the libmali dso.

column1:
In my opinion "no", I feel this is a bug in the retype code particularly the manager. Drivers in my opinion should be allowed to be pretty dumb WRT Cinder itself. We send in crap to the wrong driver I don't expect the driver to try and interpret that and come back with something.
 
 Another problem is that it might just so happen that there are multiple drivers that actually satisfy the same capability/extra-spec keys. It's certainly not an error IMO that the driver didn't know that Cinder was actually intending to "migrate" the volume.
column2:
In my opinion, "no." I believe this is a bug in the retype code, specifically the manager. Drivers, in my opinion, should be allowed to be rather ignorant regarding Cinder itself. If we pass incorrect data to the wrong driver, I don't expect the driver to try and interpret it and come up with something.

Another issue is that multiple drivers might satisfy the same capability/extra-spec keys. It's not necessarily an error, in my opinion, if the driver isn't aware that Cinder intended to "migrate" the volume.

column1: Still would be nice to join on this, just to make sure no crap is left behind. I know this thread is connected to the proxy thread running but it seems good behavior to join on both (first the proxy thread, then the notify thread). An even better way, instead of using time.sleep(pr.NOTIFY_PERIOD) from above, using a http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/threading.html#threading.Event event object, and everytime u need to sleep do self._notify_event.wait(timeout=pr.NOTIFY_PERIOD), then u can immediatly (mostly immediate) signal the notify_thread to die by just setting that event (via set()) after u stop the proxy thread.
column2: It would still be ideal to join on this to ensure no leftover mess remains. Although I know this thread is connected to the proxy thread running, it seems like good practice to join both threads (first the proxy thread and then the notify thread). An even better approach would be to use a threading.Event object instead of time.sleep(pr.NOTIFY_PERIOD) as mentioned earlier. With this, you can simply use self._notify_event.wait(timeout=pr.NOTIFY_PERIOD) whenever you need to sleep. Then, after stopping the proxy thread, you can immediately (or almost immediately) signal the notify thread to terminate by setting the event using set().

column1:
Well the logic of claiming/consuming instances is not what caused this bug (and it is well tested). What caused it is moving to and from objects in the resource tracker, and then dropping an important field due to that.
 
 So in the resource tracker we have pci pool dicts (would contain numa_node as a key), but then we convert them to objects [1] by using PciDevicePool.from_dict, which would drop the field and save it as part of tags.
 
 Upon reading them in on the scheduler side, we call PciDevicePool.to_dict, which of course will not know about the 'numa_node' since it's not on the object. For filtering to work numa_node needs to match (and it's actually gone) so all requests fail.
 
 The code in [1] merged 2 months after the patch that introduces NUMA awareness of PCI devices.
 
 TL; DR - this got borken by our neverending objects fuckery - it was not broken by definition as you seem to imply with your comments here.
 
 The commit message is misleading though so I will update it now.
 
 [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6b69b705481958bc55f9d4e29732b09a45f392a5/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L64
column2:
The issue at hand was not caused by the logic of claiming/consuming instances (which has been thoroughly tested). The problem arose when transitioning between objects in the resource tracker and accidentally dropping an important field in the process.
In the resource tracker, we have PCI pool dictionaries (which include 'numa_node' as a key), but when converting them to objects [1] using PciDevicePool.from_dict, the 'numa_node' field gets omitted and saved as part of the tags.
When reading them in the scheduler, we call PciDevicePool.to_dict, which is unaware of the 'numa_node' field since it's not present in the object. Filtering requires 'numa_node' to match (which is now missing), resulting in all requests failing.
The code in [1] was merged two months after the patch that introduced NUMA awareness of PCI devices.
To summarize, this issue was caused by the complexities of object handling, rather than being an inherent flaw as your comments might suggest.
However, I acknowledge that the commit message is misleading, and I will update it accordingly.

column1:
Yeah, it sort of sucks, but celery returns a dictionary of strings for its' event. The dictionary has a result value that is a string, but a string of a dictionary. So you have to tell python that this string is actually a dictionary, please convert it. 
 so - {u'result':u'{'some':result'}'} to {u'result:{'some':'result'}}
column2: Ah, I didn't realize that celery returns a dictionary of strings for its event. The dictionary includes a 'result' value, which is actually a string representation of another dictionary. Therefore, we need to explicitly convert that string back into a dictionary in Python. It's not the most ideal situation, but it's necessary given the circumstances.

column1:
> javascript: stupidest thing ever?

So interesting :D It seems you are asking if this can be treated as plain text. But I don't think GURL is smart enough to understand javascript syntax. Telling "javacript: stupidest thing ever?" from "javascript: var a = 0; alert(a); " would be really difficult. So is_valid() returns true for both I guess. (roughly tested but "javascript: stu..." wasn't droppable with is_valid())

> we shouldn't even try to check the Javascript scheme here,

This reminds me of our previous conversation. https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1013821/7/chrome/browser/ui/views/frame/browser_root_view.cc#180
Like !file_supported case, I think arrow on tabstrip and cursor icon should indicate that javascript scheme can't be dropped during drag session. So I think it's better to check the scheme here as long as we can.

> I also wonder if this shouldn't merge with omnibox drop handling so we just allow but auto-strip javascript: instead of banning it...

This seems to be worth trying. Let me give it a shot before long.
column2:
Interesting observation! It seems like you're asking if we can treat this as plain text. However, it's challenging for GURL to understand JavaScript syntax and differentiate between "javascript: stupidest thing ever?" and "javascript: var a = 0; alert(a);". So, I believe is_valid() returns true for both cases (roughly tested, but "javascript: stu..." wasn't droppable with is_valid()).

The reminder about our previous conversation is here: [link to the previous conversation]. Similar to the !file_supported case, I think the arrow on the tabstrip and the cursor icon should indicate that the JavaScript scheme can't be dropped during the drag session. So, checking the scheme here would be better as long as we can.

Additionally, I wonder if it would be beneficial to merge this with the omnibox drop handling, allowing but automatically stripping the "javascript:" instead of completely banning it. This approach seems worth trying, and I'll give it a shot soon.

column1:
this is already in collect_parts - we do it right before the list dir - and we *just* read the hashes pkl of the damn disk in build_reconstruction jobs - the process_job is green so we'll be going through this loop pretty fast at first.
 
 This can't be helpful to mount_check again here.
column2: This step is already included in collect_parts; we perform it just before listing the directory. Additionally, we read the hashes pkl of the disk only in build_reconstruction jobs, and since the process_job is green, we'll be moving through this loop quickly initially. There's no need to perform mount_check again at this point.

column1:
Searching for <functional> doesn't mean you find lambdas. We use it for function pointers, too. In fact, except for Igor's cmdline parser, I believe most use of lambdas has been scrubbed from the main files (the only existence is in *tests* for the optimizing compiler and one assembler [because it was the only typable way to get things done generically, languages without integrated reflection suck...]).

Don't change things, yet. I was waiting for bdc to weigh in.
column2: Searching for "<functional>" doesn't guarantee finding only lambdas. We also use it for function pointers. Most of the usage of lambdas has been removed from the main files, except in tests for the optimizing compiler and one assembler. Let's not make any changes yet; we're waiting for bdc's input.

column1: unfortunately this will no longer work. The only reason the (ugly) code on the left works is because you are calling delete on multiple rows. If you call delete on an individual object like you are doing here, it won't actually be purged because delete in the model is overridden to just update deleted=1. You'll have to do this differently. I think the "right" solution is to remove the unique constraint on name and flavorid in Instance Types and do checking in the create code to make sure you aren't creating a duplicate. This would allow deleted instance types to continue to exist. This seems preferrable as you probably want the old types to continue to exist for calculating usage, etc. This would allow us to get rid of purge entirely.
column2: Unfortunately, this approach will no longer work. When you call delete on an individual object like this, it won't be purged because the model overrides delete to update the deleted flag. We'll need to find an alternative solution. One possibility is removing the unique constraint on name and flavorid in Instance Types and performing the necessary checks during creation to avoid duplicates. This would allow deleted instance types to coexist and eliminate the need for purging entirely.

column1:
Yeah, you might need more crap here. Keys, for instance, if RPC messages start getting signed/encrypted. And yeah, other impls like zmq might have different config needs.
 
 You could punt and either put a json type blob in the DB or perhaps a configuration key name to go pull everything out of nova flags. Either way, it's probably not worth touching yet.
column2:

column1:
You should remember one simple rule: 
 
  NOBODY LIKES TO READ 
 
 You are forcing people to read bullshit. 
 
 Why not just saying in one sentece. 
 
 
  Rally allows you to set success criteria for every benchmark and check them for you. 
 
  To do that you should put in benchmark configruation one more section "sla" Like this "failure_rate": min: x max: y that means blabalbalba
 
 You can combine any of existing sla criterias. To find out of box supporting run rally info balbalbal 
 
 Then you can put ass well image with HTML report with success critera (that passed and that failed) (Overivew page of 2 benchmarks)
column2: Let's remember a simple rule: most people prefer not to read lengthy content. It would be more effective to convey the following information in a concise manner: "Rally allows you to set success criteria for each benchmark, which can be defined in the benchmark configuration under the 'sla' section. For example, 'failure_rate': min: x max: y indicates blabalbalba. You can combine various existing SLA criteria. For more details on supported options, run 'rally info balbalbal'. Additionally, consider including an image with an HTML report showcasing the success and failure criteria on the overview page of two benchmarks."

column1: Well, the rationale here is that in production you usually run at INFO level; if something were to go wrong, it sucks, as developer or admin, if we don't have access to such a key piece of information. You're left to switch to DEBUG and hope you can hit the issue again.
column2: The reasoning behind this is that in a production environment, it's typically recommended to run at the INFO level. It can be frustrating for developers or administrators not to have access to crucial information when something goes wrong. Switching to DEBUG mode and hoping to reproduce the issue is not ideal.

column1:
I can't understand why you ask me to rebase?
 Previously, you used to ask me to split this patch into 2 separate patches (for easier review). The current one is for fixing the az info issue and the second one (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149952/) is for fixing the "if not host" issue. 
 
 The modification of the guy "Hans ..." is exactly the same as my second patch which is for fixing only the issue "if not host".
 
 So, if I rebase as your wish then your previous suggestion of splitting (for easier review) will become silly and bullshit, right???
 
 You are not consistent in making review at all????
 
 I think that both of my patches should be merged to master branch at first (because I've uploaded to gerrit before that guy") and then that guy will be requested to rebase this things. That's should be the right procedure, right???
column2: I'm having trouble understanding why you're asking me to rebase. Previously, you requested that I split this patch into two separate patches for easier review. The current patch addresses the az info issue, while the second one (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149952/) resolves the "if not host" problem. The modification made by "Hans ..." is exactly the same as my second patch, which addresses only the "if not host" issue. If I rebase as per your request, it would render your previous suggestion of splitting the patches for easier review unnecessary. Could you please provide clarification? It seems that your review comments are inconsistent. My understanding is that both of my patches should be merged into the master branch first (since I uploaded them to Gerrit earlier), and then the other contributor should be asked to rebase. This approach aligns with the correct procedure, doesn't it?

column1: For me, the difference from ISE and AssertionError is that AE is an Error, that is a severe error that an application has no reason to catch, that is a bug in the implementation. Nothing to do, just crash. ISE is an exception, catchable, represent a wrong way of using an API, that is a bug in the usage, can be catchable. So, here, for me, it is an AssertionError. In addition, in Jack, we do not put message to AssertionError, unless to ass some dynamic data depending. We have all the info in the reporting to find the line.
column2: In my perspective, the difference between ise and assertionerror is that ae is an error, a severe error that an application shouldn't catch as it indicates a bug in the implementation. There is no need to take any action, just let it crash. ise, on the other hand, is an exception that can be caught and represents a wrong way of using an api, a bug in the usage that can be caught. So, here, for me, it is an assertionerror. Additionally, in jack, we don't add messages to assertionerror unless we need to include dynamic data. All the necessary information is available in the reporting to find the line.

column1:
This is horrid xenapi agent rubbish, AFAIK. This makes the agent update the networking info injected into xenstore, which can get picked up by the quark networking stack and ovs rules are updated.
 
 Reset-network is often called after inject-network to then reset the networking inside the guest using the agent, and the latest network info that has been injected.
 
 Yes, yes, its really that horrid.
column2: This section involves some unpleasant xenapi agent code, as far as my knowledge goes. It involves the agent updating the injected networking information in xenstore, which can be picked up by the quark networking stack, resulting in the update of OVS rules. The reset-network operation is often performed after inject-network to reset the networking inside the guest using the agent, considering the latest injected network info. Yes, indeed, it's truly horrid.

column1:
I totally agree with you. IMHO neutronclient is already very different from other clients and it is something "stupid". Consistency across all openstack clients is a big topic and it should be discussed and improved as a whole community and it is already raised as one of important topics in dev ML discussion. Even when we have consistency across openstack clients, I believe neutronclient will be quite different from the current one. I am not sure what is the goal of this patch. If we need further discussion over all openstack client, I think it is beyond of this patch.
 
 Consistency inside neutornclient, I agree. I don't have a strong opinion on T/F vs T/t/F/f, so I am okay to keep T/F for consistency. I would like to leave the decision to the original author.
 
 IMO we don't need to rush this for Juno release.
column2:
I completely agree with you. In my humble opinion, neutronclient is already quite distinct from other clients, and it's somewhat "inconsistent." Achieving consistency across all OpenStack clients is an important topic that should be discussed and improved by the entire community. It has already been raised as a significant topic in the dev mailing list discussions. Even when we achieve consistency across OpenStack clients, I anticipate that neutronclient will still be quite different from its current state. I'm uncertain about the goal of this patch. If we need further discussion on all OpenStack clients, I believe it goes beyond the scope of this patch.
Regarding consistency within neutronclient, I agree. I don't have a strong preference for T/F versus T/t/F/f, so I'm fine with keeping T/F for consistency. I think the decision should be left to the original author.

In my opinion, we don't need to rush this for the Juno release.

column1: So.. here's the problem with this. Even if you use a different non-db driver for the servicegroups in Nova, *there is still a service record created in the services table*. The reason is because of the (stupid) relationship between the services table and the compute_nodes table. This oddity is being addressed with the detach-service-from-compute-node blueprint which is almost entirely completed. So, bottom line... don't assume that just because the DB driver isn't configured that the services table will be empty, because it won't. :)
column2: So, here's the problem with this. Even if you use a different non-DB driver for the service groups in Nova, a service record is still created in the services table. The reason is the (unfortunate) relationship between the services table and the compute_nodes table. This peculiarity is being addressed with the "detach-service-from-compute-node" blueprint, which is nearly complete. So, the bottom line is, don't assume that the services table will be empty just because the DB driver isn't configured, because it won't be. :)

column1:
This is the ugliest extension ever made.
 The author of this extension should be hanged over a pool full of hungry crocodiles.
 
 Obviously I am its original author.
 Adding more stuff to this extension will only make the code even more unmainteinable.
 
 Personally I think external_gateway_info is one of those attributes which should be promoted to sub resource. This will simplify authz policy management, and most importantly the user workflow.
 We need to find a way where the main resource and the sub resource can be created/updated/returned in the same API request. However, if necessary, the user should be able to operate directly on the subresource.
 
 This is probably something that can't be addressed for this release cycle. So if there is any urgency around this blueprint we might proceed this way and then rework it in Kilo.
 
 However, if this patch does not make Juno, I would suggest reworking the external_gateway_info attribute (and yes, we should worry also about backward compatibility)
column2:
This is an extremely poorly designed extension.
As the original author of this extension, I should know better.
Adding more features to this extension will only make the code even more difficult to maintain.
Personally, I believe external_gateway_info should be promoted to a sub-resource. This would simplify authorization policy management and, most importantly, the user workflow.
We need to find a way to create/update/return the main resource and the sub-resource within the same API request. However, if necessary, the user should still be able to directly operate on the sub-resource.
Unfortunately, this may not be achievable within this release cycle. So, if there is an urgent need for this blueprint, we might proceed with this approach and then rework it in the next cycle.
However, if this patch doesn't make it in Juno, I suggest reworking the external_gateway_info attribute (and yes, we should also consider backward compatibility).

column2: I understand that hiding stuff with CSS can be seen as an ugly hack. If we want to reuse them with a different title, we'll need to inherit from them regardless. However, if you dislike this hack, we can consider using a different template for this table. We could inherit from the original datatable template and modify the caption block accordingly.

column1: We create a new viewholder each time the bottom sheet is pulled up. That means that every time we reset the impression tracker, we need to give it a new recycler view. This is very ugly if I try to do it from the suggestions carousel and also, it seems like it belongs in the view holder. The view holder is the thing that holds the view and shows it to the screen. So this is also where we should record that the carousel is shown.
column2: Each time the bottom sheet is pulled up, we create a new viewholder. Consequently, every time we reset the impression tracker, we need to provide it with a new recycler view. It's not ideal if we try to do this from the suggestions carousel. It seems more appropriate to handle it within the view holder. After all, the view holder's purpose is to hold and display the view, so it's where we should record that the carousel is shown.

column1:
The documentation sucks in this area. This blog describes the operation of the local certification check:
 
 https://www.percona.com/blog/2012/11/20/understanding-multi-node-writing-conflict-metrics-in-percona-xtradb-cluster-and-galera/
 
 This explains why if you take a row lock and then update that row, Galera will maintain the same ACID semantics albeit by a different mechanism: rollback instead of waiting. It doesn't need to propagate write intent locks to do this. The failure mode isn't relevant here, only that it has predictable behaviour.
 
 However, as you point out there *is* a semantic difference here because we hold a row lock while updating a different row. I hadn't considered this last time I gave this significant thought, so I need to row back on my original statement: they're clearly not the same. Don't write it off, though, because it can be used. Just not here :)
column2: The documentation in this particular area lacks clarity. I came across a helpful blog post that explains the operation of the local certification check. Here's the link: [Blog Post Link]. It describes how Galera maintains the same ACID semantics using a rollback mechanism instead of waiting, without requiring write intent locks to be propagated. While there may be a semantic difference due to holding a row lock while updating a different row, it doesn't invalidate its usefulness. However, it may not be applicable in our current context.

column2: Oops, my mistake. I was thinking that _filter_kwargs would automatically convert the trustee_user=object parameter into trustee_user_id=object.id. column1: In the interest of full disclosure, it was pointed out to me by one of my standards committee colleagues that this is not guaranteed to be the same type as int32_t, even if both exist.  (They are required to have the same size in that case.) Since this would be stupid, would result in at worst a compiled error, and we control the implementation, I don't think it matters.
column2: In the spirit of transparency, one of my colleagues from the standards committee pointed out that there is no guarantee that this will be the same type as int32_t, even if both exist (although they are required to have the same size in that case). However, since it would be illogical and result in, at worst, a compilation error, and considering that we have control over the implementation, I don't believe it significantly impacts the matter at hand.

column1:
I think you're just complicating the code by having this flag here.
 
 If you let head run past CROSSING_BUFFER_SIZE, and do the mod operation when you use it to dereference a member, then you can just compare head >= CROSSINGS_BUFFER_SIZE instead of having the double logic you have now. The only time you have to do the mod operation then is when you store a value, all other uses of head are comparisons.
 
 Nit: I'm also a sucker for "MAX_CROSSINGS" namings instead since it's a little shorter, and it clarifies if size is in bytes or entries.
column2: I think having this flag here is making the code more complicated. A possible improvement could be to allow "head" to run past CROSSING_BUFFER_SIZE and perform the modulo operation when dereferencing a member. This would simplify the logic by having a single comparison "head >= CROSSINGS_BUFFER_SIZE" in most cases, except when storing a value. As a side note, using "MAX_CROSSINGS" as a naming convention might be preferable as it's shorter and clarifies if the size refers to bytes or entries.

column1:
I strongly think that sending complete InstanceList objects for every host periodically, even if it is a longer period than 60 seconds, is a code smell. If the regular updates work well, this should never be needed. If sending such a huge amount of information regularly is needed, then the whole update process sucks and should be fixed.
 
 Alexis: I prefer the full InstanceList for a host that is not in sync, but I was anticipating that some might still see that as too heavyweight, and wanted to provide that option. We hadn't discussed this aspect of the spec at either the midcycle or the last Gantt meeting.
column2:
I strongly believe that periodically sending complete InstanceList objects for every host, even with longer intervals than 60 seconds, is a code smell. If the regular updates are functioning well, this should never be necessary. If regularly sending such a large amount of information is required, then it indicates a problem with the update process that needs to be addressed.

Alexis: I understand your preference for the full InstanceList for hosts that are not in sync. However, I anticipated that some might find it too resource-intensive, so providing that option was important. We didn't discuss this aspect of the specification during the midcycle or the last Gantt meeting.

column1:
To be fair, force volume detach sounds essentially the same as force delete of an instance, the only difference with normal delete is the state checking. So if we're OK with forced instance delete, why is forced volume detach so terrible, knowing it's a last resort and yes the recovery/rollback/cleanup of failed attach/detach operations should be fixed as bug fixes?
 
 For example, in the case of a network outage or something which shouldn't happen but shit happens, and things get out of whack, I really only see (1) force detach API, (2) periodic cleanup task, or (3) manual intervention in the database from the operator, which kind of sucks.
column2: To be fair, "force volume detach" essentially has the same effect as a forced instance delete. The only difference is the state checking. So if we are okay with forced instance deletion, why should forced volume detach be considered terrible? It should be treated as a last resort. Additionally, the recovery, rollback, and cleanup of failed attach/detach operations should be addressed as bug fixes. For instance, in the event of a network outage or unexpected issues, we might need to consider (1) a force detach API, (2) periodic cleanup tasks, or (3) manual intervention in the database from the operator. These options may not be ideal, but they could be necessary.

column2: Ideally, I would prefer to see this implemented as a #define, but finding a suitable location for it is a bit challenging. The plat/pm.h file seems like the easiest spot since it already contains the existing pm_check code, but including it here would result in some untidiness. Conceptually, I'm not entirely sure what the best approach would be here.

column1:
Oh damn it's so misleading.
 
  stack@virtual-machine:~/devstack$ lsb_release -a
  No LSB modules are available.
  Distributor ID: Ubuntu
  Description: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS
  Release: 14.04
  Codename: trusty
 
  stack@virtual-machine:~/devstack$ sudo apt-cache search docker 
  ...
  docker - System tray for KDE3/GNOME2 docklet applications
  docker.io - Linux container runtime
  ...
column2:
Oh, this is quite misleading. If you run "lsb_release -a" on the virtual machine, it provides the following output:

No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS
Release: 14.04
Codename: trusty

When you execute "sudo apt-cache search docker", you get results such as:

docker - System tray for KDE3/GNOME2 docklet applications
docker.io - Linux container runtime

column1:
I am using:
 pblendw
 psrlw
instead of:
 punpckldq
 punpckhdq

On Sandy/Ivy Bridge there is now difference, but Haswell/Skylake has only 1 vector permute (shuffle) unit so 2 punpck cannot issue in parallel in these later machines, while blendw and shift can issue in parallel (shit uses the vector ALU, blendw uses the vector permute unit) on all 4 of these micro-architectures.
column2: Instead of using punpckldq and punpckhdq, I'm utilizing pblendw and psrlw. While Sandy/Ivy Bridge machines show no difference, on Haswell/Skylake machines, only one vector permute (shuffle) unit is available. As a result, punpck instructions cannot be issued in parallel, whereas blendw and shift instructions can be issued in parallel. This holds true for all four micro-architectures mentioned.

column2:

column1:
This is needed for "!ERRORLEVEL!" thingies below.

As far as I understood, 'if ()' statements are parsed as a single "line" in one go. By default (without delayed expansion), interpreter substitutes variable values right away. So if %ERRORLEVEL% was 0 _BEFORE_ if (), it is also 0 inside 'if', regardless of any calls there. 

I spend 3h trying to figure out this shit :( It is highly confusing...

Using !ERRORLEVEL! tells the interpreter not to expand anything until the statement is really executed.
column2:
This section requires the use of "!ERRORLEVEL!".
Based on my understanding, 'if ()' statements are treated as a single "line" with immediate variable substitution. Therefore, if %ERRORLEVEL% was 0 BEFORE entering the 'if' statement, it would remain 0 inside 'if', regardless of any subsequent calls.
I spent three hours grappling with this confusing behavior. To delay expansion, we utilize !ERRORLEVEL!, which instructs the interpreter not to expand anything until the statement is executed.

column1:
Actually it would be stupid easy to screw this up. Set BASE_IMAGE_FILE to a precise image of some sort without changing anything else and bam, this is broken again for no obvious reason.

column2: We should be cautious as it can be quite easy to unintentionally break this functionality. To avoid any unexpected issues, let's set "BASE_IMAGE_FILE" to a specific image without modifying anything else. Additionally, using "DIB_RELEASE" for version checks might not be the best practice, considering it currently specifies the image version to download. We should reconsider our configuration approach.

column1:
one difference between you and Chrome is that they build with the NDK and you build with the platform. so to you, there's one bionic and it's already the latest. they might want to #include <android/api-level.h> #if __BIONIC__ and then they can say things like "if i'm >= jellybean, i have function f" or whatever.

(now we've inherited the NDK, we plan to make a lot of this crap go away via static linking, but that's a way in the future yet.)
column2: There's a distinction between our approach and Chrome's. They build with the NDK while we build with the platform. To handle this difference, they may include <android/api-level.h> and conditionally use certain functions based on the Android version. We plan to improve this situation in the future by reducing the reliance on such mechanisms through static linking.

column1:

A std::vector<char> could have worked better here or wrapping the strdup() with std::unique_ptr, but hopefully we'll get rid of this copying once and for all with https://android-review.googlesource.com/#/c/162655/
column2: Initially, using "&data[0]" was my idea, but it would require modifying the parameter list (removing "const") or using an unsightly "const_cast<>" operation. Additionally, it's best to avoid directly modifying a std::string. Perhaps we can improve this situation once and for all with the proposed changes in this link: https://android-review.googlesource.com/#/c/162655/

column1:
For optional arguments (retries, gsutil_opts, etc), pass by name, not positionally; positionally basically makes your life suck if you have to refactor the API (say remove a keyword, or add a new one, etc).

Note that rule is basically true 98% of the time; the exception is for methods like {}.get, which is 'def get(self, key, default=None)'; in that case, since the API is never going to expand/change/etc, positionally passing 'default' is fine.

For _GsUpload, that doesn't apply; note this commentary/issue applies for all other usages of _GsUpload (this is the one I noticed, haven't checked the others for the same issue).
column2: When dealing with optional arguments like retries and gsutil_opts, it's best to pass them by name rather than positionally. Positional passing can lead to difficulties when refactoring the API. However, note that for methods like {}.get, where the API is unlikely to change, it's acceptable to pass "default" positionally.

column1:
hm, right... it sucks.
 The idea is to evaluate next alarms for 'and' conditional op if previous alarms are UNKW .. but it doesn't work here if all are UNKW.
 
 To implement such behavior I need to keep all previous state and set UNKW if all are UNKW.
 
 It will be easier to have expected behavior: stop at the first evaluation not matching the first rule.
column2: Ah, yes, this situation is frustrating. Currently, the evaluation of the next alarms for the "and" conditional operation doesn't work as intended if all previous alarms are "UNKW." To implement the desired behavior, we need to keep track of all previous states and set "UNKW" if they are all "UNKW." It would be simpler to stop the evaluation at the first rule that doesn't match.

Does Brillo support platform development on Windows? It seems that Android doesn't. Additionally, I'm starting to question the necessity of this approach. While we're executing commands, it's quite limited in functionality. It appears to be mimicking shell behavior, but we already have reliable shells in place. The provided provisioning script looks nearly identical to a shell script, with each line starting with "fastboot." This approach leaves too much room for hacks, especially when accommodating custom requirements from OEMs. Considering the complexity, using Python or even a .bat file might be sufficient.

column1:
the issue is with testManifestVersionedSyncOnePartBranch.  it stubs out manifest_version.BuildSpecsManager which is responsible for initializing manifest_version.current_version.  that means it stays at the object default of None.

then when the ManifestVersionedSyncStage.GetNextManifest runs, it tries to use manifest_version.current_version (which is still None) and we hit this error here when we try to print out None.

there's multiple ways to fix this, but they all kind of suck.  the test is trying to exercise just the stage without getting too much into the manifest_version internals.  so i put the str() here.

it's a non-issue for ForceVersion because it is given a real string rather than pulling out an uninitialized (due to test stubbing) version of None.
column2: Oops, thanks for pointing out the issue. In the testManifestVersionedSyncOnePartBranch, where manifest_version.BuildSpecsManager is stubbed out, it fails to initialize manifest_version.current_version, resulting in the "None" error when trying to print it. There are multiple ways to address this problem, but they all have their downsides. The purpose of the test is to focus on the stage itself without delving too much into the internals of manifest_version. I added the str() function here to avoid the error. Fortunately, for ForceVersion, a real string is provided instead of an uninitialized version of None, so this issue doesn't occur there.

column1: As is, this won't work. These wrapper objects are keyed off of their backing view/widget/window. There are still references to GetID using the AXAuraObjCache in AXWindowObjWrapper, for instance. There would be a weird split between the AXWindowObjWrapper using AXAuraObjCache id's and AXViewWrapper using ids from your unique id counter and they won't be guaranteed to be unique...
column2: As it stands, this won't work. These wrapper objects are associated with their respective backing view/widget/window. There are references to GetID in AXWindowObjWrapper, for example, that rely on AXAuraObjCache. If we introduce a split, with AXWindowObjWrapper using AXAuraObjCache IDs and AXViewWrapper using unique IDs from your counter, there's no guarantee of uniqueness. We need to find a solution that ensures unique IDs across both wrapper types.

column1:
does Brillo support platform development on Windows? Android doesn't.

otherwise, i'm starting to think this is a mistake. we're doing command execution, but only in a very limited form. we're doing environment variable substitution, but badly. it feels like the best we can hope for is to achieve parity with the shell --- but we already have perfectly good shells.

your example provisioning script looks identical as a shell script except that each line starts with "fastboot ".

the "too much room for hacks" is probably a good thing --- sooner or later there's going to be some custom bullshit an OEM needs you to do, and then you either hack that in to fastboot or have a separate shell script you need to run in addition to "fastboot provision". this is why Android's init is such an awful mess. they wanted it to be "minimal" but bad things happen when you collide with reality. especially in areas where OEMs are involved. the recovery image links in an arbitrary OEM-provided .so to solve the equivalent problem there. yeah, the shell's not lovely, but the alternatives all tend to be worse...

i think "Windows" is really the only strong counter-argument, and even there that just makes me think "python" rather than "shell". (although for the level of complexity you're talking about, a .bat file is probably sufficient anyway.)
column2: Does Brillo support platform development on Windows? Android doesn't. Frankly, I'm starting to think this might be a mistake. Although we're executing commands, it's highly limited in scope. We're attempting environment variable substitution, but not doing it well. At best, we'll achieve parity with the shell, but we already have reliable shells in place. The provisioning script provided as an example looks identical to a shell script, with each line beginning with "fastboot." The potential for hacks is significant, especially when accommodating custom requirements from OEMs. The complexity of the situation makes me lean towards using Python or even a .bat file, which might suffice.

column1: To my knowledge it doesn't modify their model -- it just reads from it to set up the tree view. If you add/remove entire modules, I think some of their code I didn't touch may muck around in IJ's representation of module structure. Sigh, I know that sucks. I'll have to talk with Alex to see how we want to synchronize with Gradle -- it used to pick up changes automatically, but he just modified that to keep it from kicking off import tasks while you're editing the build files by hand.
column2: As far as I know, this doesn't modify their model; it simply reads from it to set up the tree view. If you add or remove entire modules, there's a possibility that some untouched code in IntelliJ's representation of module structure may interfere. I understand the frustration, and I'll discuss with Alex to determine how we should synchronize with Gradle. Previously, changes were detected automatically, but he recently made adjustments to prevent import tasks from running while manually editing the build files.

yes. The problem is really about the 'params' (damn the name). How are we viewing it. Are they parameters to the 'cluster_check' operation, or they are parameters to the 'register_cluster' operation. If they are for the cluster_check operation, we should leave them to that operation to find out the contents inside. If they are parameters to the 'register_cluster' function, we can leave it as '**params' for sure.
 
 Hope you finally get my point. And, very sorry for blocking this for a long time.
column2: Yes, the issue primarily revolves around the 'params' variable (unfortunately named). We need to determine how we interpret its contents. Are these parameters specifically for the 'cluster_check' operation, or are they meant for the 'register_cluster' operation? If they are intended for 'cluster_check', we should let that operation handle the extraction of the internal contents. However, if they are parameters for the 'register_cluster' function, we can keep using '**params' as it is.

column1:
General robustness nit (bit of style in particular):

Don't assign to the attribute intermediate values.  You mangle the hell out of boto_file throughout the following values- assign once the value has stabilized.

The reasons for this style don't strictly apply here, but the style should be used regardless since it's good form; basically, if ever dealing w/ cpy initializers, threading, etc, take your pick, having intermediate assignment like this means you've got varying state that can bite you in the ass.

Worse, if the init method goes and invokes methods to finish initialization, if an intermediate value is stashed on the instance, the method can use that value w/out you getting an AttributeError; etc, thus assign once stable.

Upshot, the form I mentioned is safer, and it's also marginally faster (the latter is true, but so small it's more a joke than a valid reason exempting extreme cases ;) )
column2: Here's a suggestion for better code style: Instead of assigning intermediate values to the attribute 'boto_file' repeatedly, let's assign the value once it has stabilized. This approach improves safety and can potentially enhance performance.

column1: From operator's POV, it would look like your damn service just started to fail and need reboot like a damn Windows machine (this isn't an actual wording, it'll be stronger). And there will come autorestart cron jobs etc. If daemon is run from some RC system, it'll most likely just restart it automatically. So either way you'll have some restart logic, why not put it all in one place?
column2: From an operator's perspective, it may give the impression that the service has failed and needs a reboot, resembling a Windows machine. This can lead to auto-restart cron jobs and other unintended consequences. Instead, let's consolidate the restart logic in one place to avoid confusion and potential issues.

column1:
POSIX says "unsigned long". so we can:

1. go with POSIX, and have to add struct statvfs64, statvfs64, and fstatvfs64 later.

2. go straight to 64-bit for statvfs but break expectations about these types. (in printf format strings, say.)

this patch takes option 1. it makes me slightly sad, but i figure it's only a small extra helping of turd on top of the big fat turd we already have.
column2: According to POSIX, the type should be "unsigned long." This patch takes option 1, even though it's not ideal. It's a small compromise to avoid further complications.

column1:
is this script installed on every device ? if not, there needs to be a check & message at the top.
 
 the script itself seems to have a 60 second sleep. that seems pointless here.
 
 ec_sb_firmware_update is allowed to run & update things as the "chronos" user ? that seems fundamentally flawed from a security perspective. normally crosh makes requests to the system via dbus & debugd and that takes care of elevated permissions.
 
 along those lines, since you're running this directly as the user, what's to stop them from hitting CTRL+C in the middle and screwing things up ?
column2: Could we verify if this script is installed on every device? If not, it would be helpful to include a check and message at the top to ensure proper usage. Additionally, the 60-second sleep in the script seems unnecessary for this particular scenario. Furthermore, we should reconsider the security perspective of allowing ec_sb_firmware_update to run and update things as the "chronos" user. Typically, crosh handles system requests via dbus and debugd, which ensures elevated permissions are managed appropriately. Also, let's address the concern of users potentially interrupting the process by hitting CTRL+C and causing disruptions.

column1:
hang on, thats rubbish, ignore that idea.
 
 I kinda think if we want CONF.image_cache_subdirectory_name to mean the same for vmware and libvirt, if possible.
 
 If we added a CONF.vmware.make_cache_folder_unique that controlled if you add the my_ip to the CONF.image_cache_subdirectory_name, it would be much simpler.
 
 Admins that want to share the folder, then just set CONF.vmware.make_cache_folder_unique=False, then they configure the cache directly, just like libvirt folks, by configuring CONF.image_cache_subdirectory_name
column2: It appears that the current approach may not be the best solution. Let's reconsider the idea of having CONF.image_cache_subdirectory_name mean the same for both vmware and libvirt. One possible improvement is to introduce a new configuration option called CONF.vmware.make_cache_folder_unique. This option would control whether the my_ip should be added to CONF.image_cache_subdirectory_name. By implementing this change, we can simplify the configuration process. Admins who want to share the folder can set CONF.vmware.make_cache_folder_unique to False and configure the cache directly, similar to the approach used by libvirt.

column1:
monkeypatching ftw!
 
 In all seriousness, monkeypatching sucks and we only use it as a method of last resort. enable_sudo_enabled_check is a bit too vague for my liking, so consider changing the name of the method to something like 'patch_create_process' so that it's apparent to anyone looking at the invocation what is happening.
column2: Although monkeypatching can be useful in certain cases, it is generally not recommended and should be used only as a last resort. In this context, the method enable_sudo_enabled_check could benefit from a more descriptive name, such as 'patch_create_process'. Renaming the method to something more intuitive would make it clear to anyone reading the code what exactly is happening.

column1: That sucks.  These three firmware-reading steps completely dominate the running time.  Doing the other stuff in parallel will not buy much...  Current running time is 15s (with a broken touchpad probe, which seems to be broken just on my alex, but might be fixed by reboot).  Of this, only 2s is "other stuff"...  It would seem like EC and main FW should be able to run in parallel, since they use separate buses, no?
column2: That's disappointing. These three firmware-reading steps significantly impact the running time. Even if we perform the other tasks in parallel, the improvement will be minimal. Currently, the running time is 15 seconds, with the touchpad probe issue (which might be resolved by rebooting). Only 2 seconds are spent on tasks other than firmware reading. It seems like the EC and main FW should be able to run in parallel since they use separate buses, right?

column1: We seem to use gcc4.6 in L for host builds.  For example, the bionic tests on glibc run with 4.6 in L.  There is a 4.6 host prebuilt tree in L, which seems to get used heavily.  In all of those cases, we fall back to the __sync implementations.  Those are stupid ans slow, so hopefully this is not true for anything where performance matters.  This was not my choice. Someone explained the reason to me, but I don't recall it at the moment.
column2:
In L, we seem to use gcc4.6 for host builds. For example, the bionic tests on glibc run with 4.6 in L. There is a prebuilt tree for 4.6 hosts in L, which is heavily used. In all these cases, we fall back to using the __sync implementations. Although they are slow and inefficient, I hope this doesn't affect any performance-critical scenarios. I don't recall the exact reason for this decision, but it was not mine to make.

Please let me know if you have any further questions or if there's anything else I can assist you with.
