column1: It's prior to the standard libs because eventlet.monkey_patch() monkey patches core primitives in Python and if it doesn't happen first thing you get into serious fuckery when it tries to use a non-patched package like time in a patched package.
column2: The reason eventlet.monkey_patch() is placed before the standard libs is because it needs to patch core primitives in Python. Otherwise, it causes issues when using a non-patched package like time within a patched package.

column1: It would be nice to offer 2 (at least) redis and sqlalchemy. column1:
Note that we could potentially put this inside the context and add a function templates.Extra(c) (or something) to get it, but I decided against it because:
 
 * I believe explicit argument is a more friendly API. No spooky action at a distance, no functions to learn.
 * There's a lot of crap already in our contexts. And the context is organized as linked list with O(N) access time, more crap => slower.
column2: One alternative approach could be placing this functionality inside the context and introducing a function like templates.Extra(c) to retrieve it. However, after careful consideration, I decided against it for a few reasons: First, I believe having an explicit argument provides a more intuitive and user-friendly API without any hidden surprises. Second, our contexts are already quite cluttered, and adding more elements would result in slower access times due to the linked list organization. Hence, I opted for the current approach, but I'm open to discussing other ideas.

Just a small nitpick for C functions (not C++): it's advisable to use a (void) parameter to indicate that the function takes no arguments. Without it, the compiler assumes the function can accept any number of parameters. This is a legacy C issue. For more details, please refer to this Stack Overflow discussion: [link]

column1:
Ah, damn - good catch! You're making me rethink the way we are doing things here. Essentially, all we really want to do is make sure that what is in CryptAuth matches the current GcmDeviceInfo.

Now that I think about it more, we probably don't need to store anything in preferences at all. I think we could just do the following:

(1) Inspect the GcmDeviceInfo and the local device metadata. If they contain the same supported features, we are done.
(2) If they do not, then force enrollment/sync until they contain the same supported features.

In this scheme, we wouldn't need to worry about the ListValues at all, since we wouldn't be storing any values in preferences. We could just extract a std::vector<cryptauth::SoftwareFeature> from both the GcmDeviceInfo and local device metadata. What do you think about this idea? Do you see anything that could go wrong here?
column2: Ah, I see your point. You're making me reconsider our approach here. Ultimately, our goal is to ensure that CryptAuth matches the current GcmDeviceInfo accurately. Upon further thought, we might not need to store anything in preferences. Here's an alternative proposal: (1) Compare the GcmDeviceInfo with the local device metadata and check if they contain the same supported features. If they do, we're done. (2) If they don't, enforce enrollment/sync until they align. In this scheme, we won't need to worry about ListValues because we won't be storing any values in preferences. We can simply extract a std::vectorcryptauth::SoftwareFeature from both GcmDeviceInfo and local device metadata. What are your thoughts on this idea? Do you foresee any potential issues or complications?

i misunderstood what you were asking. (there are too damn many different kinds of macros, all with very similar names!)

i thought you were asking about macros like _POSIX_ADVISORY_INFO which must always be defined, but whose value tells you whether their feature is supported. obviously these ones need to be defined.

but now i guess you were actually talking about ones like _POSIX_SS_REPL_MAX which should _not_ be defined if you don't have the optional feature it belongs to. obviously these ones need to _not_ be defined.

as for _POSIX2_FORT_DEV, note the "if" in what POSIX actually says: "If this symbol is defined in <unistd.h>, it shall be defined to be -1, 0, or 200809L.". the little "[FD]" next to the name means that this is part of the optional extra FD (Fortran Development). we don't have that, so we don't need to have any of the defines, and it's probably less confusing to just remove them. (though, as you say, in this case at least they let us set it to -1.)

if glibc doesn't have a macro, that probably means we don't need to either (and also probably means we _shouldn't_ have it --- i can't think of any part of POSIX we support that they don't).
column2: I misunderstood your question. There are indeed numerous macros with similar names, and it can be confusing. For instance, macros like _POSIX_ADVISORY_INFO must always be defined, as their value indicates whether the associated feature is supported. On the other hand, macros like _POSIX_SS_REPL_MAX should not be defined if the optional feature is not available. We don't need these defines because we don't have the extra FD (Fortran Development) feature. Therefore, it's best to remove them. If glibc doesn't have a particular macro, it's likely that we don't need it either, as we aim to support only the POSIX features available in glibc.

column1:
(It took me a month to understand what this code was supposed to do, so who is being stupid here?:).
First, I find out if the destination is 1 cell or a range, and if the source area is large than the selected destination area [1271-1279]. The largest area of these is taken for the comparisons [1282-1283], as this will be the actual destination area (copy/paste some blocks and you will see what I mean if my text is not clear).
The first comparison is whether source and destination area overlap [1284-1288]. When the source area contains references, these probably will go wrong when there is an overlap. As this may produce data loss (e.g. formulas that get wrong references), it _must_ be avoided. This code was there from the beginning, but with errors, disabling the wrong options. My first patch fixed only a part of that.
The second comparison [1294-1327] handles something else, the question whether shifting the cells in the destination area will fit on the sheet. This comparison is not necessary for integrity, but for user friendliness. Without the comparison, the user will get a message that the result will not fit and no harm is done. Rainer Bielefeld wanted the possibilty of fitting on the sheet reflected in the en/disabling of the shift options.
I do this check by going from the MAXCOL/MAXROW position back for the width/height of the destination area and checking if the cells are empty. If not, paste+shift will not fit and the appropiate shit option is disabled.
I feared a performance penalty with this method, but I tested it on an old. slow machine (complete build of Libreofiice takes 24hrs) with a destination area almost MAXROW high and that gave no noticeable delay.
But because of this performance penalty danger, i want you to have a good look at the code. Perhaps it will be safer to leave it out, perhaps there are more efficient ways to check the fitting.

I hope my proze give you the explanation you want.
Perhaps I should put some of it in the code as comment?
column2: It took me a while to fully understand the purpose of this code, so perhaps the clarity could be improved. Allow me to explain: First, I determine whether the destination is a single cell or a range, and if the source area is larger than the selected destination area [1271-1279]. To compare the areas accurately, I choose the largest area [1282-1283] as the actual destination area. Please note that the initial comparison checks for any overlap between the source and destination areas [1284-1288]. If the source area contains references, an overlap can lead to incorrect results, potentially causing data loss (e.g., formulas with incorrect references). Therefore, it's crucial to avoid such overlap. The code you see was present from the beginning but contained errors that disabled the wrong options. My previous patch resolved part of the issue. Additionally, the second comparison [1294-1327] addresses a different aspect: whether shifting the cells in the destination area will fit within the sheet. Although this comparison isn't necessary for maintaining data integrity, it contributes to user-friendliness. Without this check, the user would receive a message indicating that the result won't fit, but no actual harm would occur. Rainer Bielefeld requested the ability to enable or disable shift options based on whether they would fit on the sheet. To achieve this, I traverse the destination area backward, starting from the MAXCOL/MAXROW position and checking if the cells are empty. If they are not, it means that pasting and shifting won't fit, and the corresponding shift option should be disabled. While I had concerns about potential performance issues, I conducted tests on an old, slow machine (a complete build of LibreOffice takes 24 hours), using a destination area nearly as high as MAXROW, and no noticeable delay occurred. Nevertheless, due to the possible performance impact, I would appreciate a thorough review of the code. Perhaps there are more efficient ways to accomplish the desired check.

column1:
Well, we can either bail or not bail here.

If we bail, then we have to propagate that error all the way back up to the user, which sucks a lot; if we don't bail, we'll never migrate those directories. If we do propagate it up, the user's stuck with half of their cryptohome moved and half of it not moved. Ugh.
column2:
We are faced with a decision here - whether to bail out or not.
If we choose to bail out, we would need to propagate that error all the way back up to the user, which is highly undesirable. However, if we decide not to bail out, we will never migrate those directories. It's important to consider the implications of both options. If we propagate the error, the user will be left with half of their cryptohome moved and the other half not moved, resulting in an inconvenient situation. On the other hand, if we don't propagate the error, we won't migrate those directories at all. It's a challenging trade-off, and we need to carefully weigh the pros and cons before making a decision.

column1:
Eh?  We're not killing here, we're looping over any ondisk groups, trying to wipe them via RemoveThisGroup (which goes recursive).

We have to do this because from an API perspective, we can't just wipe ourselves then recreate.  Well, we could, but that sucks since it'd blow away any settings that had been pushed into our group (things like memory limits, cpu affinity, etc).
column2: Oh, sorry for the confusion. We're not killing anything here; instead, we're looping over any on-disk groups and using RemoveThisGroup to wipe them recursively. This approach is necessary because, from an API perspective, we can't simply wipe ourselves and recreate. Although it may seem convoluted, it ensures that any settings pushed into our group, such as memory limits or CPU affinity, are preserved. So, it's essential to continue with this loop.

column1:
Yep, but if you want to actually be clean on versions, you should make the call the way it was. Later, when it's 3am, shit is on fire, and you're looking at raw messages on the bus trying to figure out what is going on, you'll appreciate diligence here :P
 
 Further, assuming you'll have some other RPC stuff in ironic to clean up, you'll want to not have any implicit assumptions in places in the code that will teach people to do the wrong thing in places where the assumptions don't hold. We have the same conductor-first rule, but we try (and generally succeed) to make our clients and servers clean all the time so nobody gets confused why it's okay to cheat here and not there.
column2: Yes, you're right. However, if we want to ensure clean versioning, we should make the call the way it was. Trust me, when it's 3 am and everything is going haywire, and you're sifting through raw messages trying to figure out what's happening, you'll appreciate the diligence here. Furthermore, assuming we'll have more RPC-related tasks in Ironic that require cleanup, we should avoid implicit assumptions in the code that might confuse people into doing the wrong thing in different scenarios. While we have the conductor-first rule, let's strive for clean clients and servers consistently to avoid any confusion about when it's okay to take shortcuts and when it's not.

column1:
For optional arguments (retries, gsutil_opts, etc), pass by name, not positionally; positionally basically makes your life suck if you have to refactor the API (say remove a keyword, or add a new one, etc).
 
 Note that rule is basically true 98% of the time; the exception is for methods like {}.get, which is 'def get(self, key, default=None)'; in that case, since the API is never going to expand/change/etc, positionally passing 'default' is fine.
 
 For _GsUpload, that doesn't apply; note this commentary/issue applies for all other usages of _GsUpload (this is the one I noticed, haven't checked the others for the same issue).
column2: For optional arguments like retries and gsutil_opts, it's better to pass them by name instead of position. Positional passing can lead to headaches when refactoring the API, such as removing or adding a new keyword. Note that this rule generally applies 98% of the time. The exception is for methods like {}.get, which has 'def get(self, key, default=None)'. In that case, it's fine to pass 'default' positionally since the API is not expected to change. However, for _GsUpload, this rule doesn't apply. Please keep in mind that this comment applies to all other usages of _GsUpload as well (I've only noticed it in this case, haven't checked other instances for the same issue).

column2:

column1: The sucky thing here is that well output multiple PUBLICs with the same name. That might confuse the processor (or at least it could in theory, but it may not in practice). Itll certainly confuse humans, though: if you thought you knew what RtlCaptureContext + 9 meant, think again. I wonder if we should introduce our own mangling, like ${reserved_or_unlikely_char}${original_symbol_name}_block_${number}.
column2: The problem here is that we'll end up with multiple PUBLICs having the same name. This can potentially confuse the processor (or at least confuse humans trying to understand it). I wonder if we should introduce our own symbol mangling scheme, like ${reserved_or_unlikely_char}${original_symbol_name}block${number}.

column1: It is needed. See the PEP. The way I understand it, in order for the n+1st-loaded package to be able to compose into the namespace, the nth package's __init__.py has to have this in it. We don't know of a scenario where someone other than us will be playing in this space, but it would be a dick move to prevent it.
column2: It is necessary. Please refer to the PEP for more information. From my understanding, in order for the n+1st-loaded package to be able to compose into the namespace, the nth package's __init__.py file needs to include this. While we don't anticipate scenarios where someone other than us will be using this, it would be unfair to prevent it.

column1:
1 & 3) See earlier comments about fiddling w/ the patch (multiple times, leading to the current el busto'd form) to get gerrit to actually take the CL. Emails already sent to pull the gerrit logs and run down that cause.
 
 2) Yeah, I'm a moron, that was there prior to the gerrit mayhem.
 
 4) This pathway in general for this is wrong, including prior to my changes; it would allow throwing out a newer version of a dep during this fallback testing, being inaccurate.
 
 Frankly not particularly sure if it's even worth maintaining the "you should update to ToT vs patch conflict" bits- the conflict detection/handling really, really is at the wrong layer here.
 
 Sorely tempted to rip it out unless someone thinks it's worth keeping- which case it would have to be at the validation pool layer...
column2:
Regarding the fiddling with the patch multiple times to get it accepted in Gerrit, I have already sent emails to retrieve the Gerrit logs and investigate the cause.
Yes, that mistake was present before the Gerrit issues.
In general, this pathway for handling fallback testing is incorrect, even prior to my changes. It allows for the exclusion of newer versions of dependencies during the fallback, resulting in inaccuracies.
Frankly, I'm not entirely convinced if maintaining the "update to ToT vs. patch conflict" mechanism is worth it. The conflict detection and handling need to be addressed at a different level. I'm tempted to remove it unless there is a strong argument for keeping it, in which case it should be handled at the validation pool layer.

column1:
I'm not loving this direct reliance on __module__ == 'ceilometer.storage.base', seems brittle to me.
 
 Why not just change the EventsNotificationEndpoint instead, to adopt a suck-it-and-see approach on the call into record_events?
 
 i.e. wrap this call:
 
  https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/event/endpoint.py#L67
 
 in a try-except-NotImplementedError block, and simply fall out to marking the notification as HANDLED in that case?
column2: I have reservations about directly relying on __module__ == 'ceilometer.storage.base'. It appears somewhat fragile to me. Instead, why not modify the EventsNotificationEndpoint and handle the call into record_events with a try-except block for NotImplementedError? In such cases, we can mark the notification as "HANDLED."

column1:
we used to have procfs.h until very recently. there used to be a copy in bionic and another forked copy for the NDK stuff. i removed bionic's copy when we removed libthread_db from bionic, on the understanding that -- since both are only useful for gdb -- the "true" copy should be with gdb.

but now it looks like we're committing random hacks against gdb instead? that's fucked up.
column2: We used to have procfs.h until recently, with copies in both bionic and the NDK. I removed the copy in bionic when we eliminated libthread_db from it, assuming that the "true" copy should be with gdb. But it seems like we're now applying random hacks against gdb? That's not ideal.

column1:
This hurts my brain, and I like partial normally. :)

You're damn close however: try this instead:

self.http_client.request = Self._RetryRequest(self.http_client.request)

Note that http_client is an instance, so grabbing it's instancemethod like above, gets you an instancemethod- meaning self is prebound.  No need to do the class shenanigans.  Downside, it creates a reference cycle, but you've already got them here.
column2: This is a bit challenging for me, and I generally prefer using partial. However, you're very close to the solution. Try this instead: self.http_client.request = Self._RetryRequest(self.http_client.request). Note that http_client is an instance, so by accessing its instance method as shown above, self is already prebound. There's no need for the class shenanigans. The only downside is that it creates a reference cycle, but that's already the case here.

column1:
> this isn't really good form because if someone implements these methods for Kitkat one, they won't know there is this corner case that doesn't work.
> 
> probably better to pass in the bool in the Lollipop (and higher) constructor instead. Then if someone wants to use attached state in kitkat one, at least they'll realize the initial value is missing, and then fix tracking properly. That does mean inlining WebContentsAccessibility.create here though, which kind of sucks..

Or maybe it's easier to just put a comment in the kitkat one that mentions this corner case
column2: It would be beneficial to consider an alternative approach here. Instead of relying on someone implementing these methods for Kitkat, it might be better to pass in a boolean value in the Lollipop (and higher) constructor. This way, if someone intends to use attached state in Kitkat, they will be aware of the missing initial value and can properly address the tracking. Another option could be to include a comment in the Kitkat method, highlighting this corner case.

column1:
We don't need to call collect_au_log in the first place if log_dir is missing.

>why don't just let collect_au_log to check any parameter it gets in?
That kind of implicit handling is bad, it's how you end up with JavaScript:

    > '5' - 3
    2        // weak typing + implicit conversions = headaches
    > '5' + 3
    '53'     // Because we all love consistency
    > '5' - '4'
    1        // string - string = integer. What?
    > '5' + + '5'
    '55'
    > 'foo' + + 'foo'
    'fooNaN' // Marvelous.
    > '5' + - '2'
    '5-2'
    > '5' + - + - - + - - + + - + - + - + - - - '-2'
    '52'     // Apparently it's ok
    
    > var x = 3;
    > '5' + x - x
    50
    > '5' - x + x
    5      // Because fuck math
column2: Instead of invoking collect_au_log unnecessarily when log_dir is missing, let's consider enhancing collect_au_log to validate any parameter it receives. Implicit handling like this can lead to issues, as demonstrated by the example with JavaScript. It's always better to have explicit and consistent behavior.

column1: Ick. resource_data is such a nasty internal hack. Not as nasty as what we used to do with metadata, of course, but still... is there any way we can not expose this to the user? column2: The usage of resource_data as an internal hack seems rather unpleasant. Although not as terrible as what we used to do with metadata, it would be ideal to find a way to avoid exposing this to the user. Perhaps we can disallow external references for resource types that have resource data, considering that most of them lack a sensible external resource_id. Can we identify the potential impact of such a change?

Why are service providers treated differently from IaaS services? In my opinion, they could be treated as another type of service. How about considering them in a similar way? Here's a suggestion:

{
  "id": "...",
  "type": "identity-service-provider",
  "name": "example",
  "interface": "auth",
  "url": "https://example.com:5000/v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/acme/protocols/saml2/auth"
},
{
  "id": "...",
  "type": "identity-service-provider",
  "name": "example",
  "interface": "service",
  "url": "https://other.example.com:5000/Shibboleth.sso/SAML2/ECP"
}

column1:
Same reasoning given for GerritHelper.__init__ .

When doing default arguments/fallbacks like this, one needs to be *extremely* explicit in the check else you can get bit in the ass pretty easily.

Consider the following prototype:

def DoSomeStuff(myargs, cache_override=None):
  if not cache_override:
    cache_override = self._internal_cache
  self._ReallyDoStuff(myargs, cache_override)

It's subtle, but that block of code will incorrectly fallback to the internal cache if the passed in cache_override is {} (which may be entirely intentional- to force a run w/out using internal caches values).

If you use the 'is None', check, it handles it correctly.  The only ass biter in scenarios like that is when you need to detect if None was explicitly passed in, in which case you use an object() singleton to detect it.
column2:
Similar reasoning applies to GerritHelper.init.
When using default arguments or fallbacks like this, it's crucial to be extremely explicit in the check. Otherwise, it can lead to issues. Consider the following prototype as an example:

def DoSomeStuff(myargs, cache_override=None):
  if not cache_override:
    cache_override = self._internal_cache
  self._ReallyDoStuff(myargs, cache_override)
It's subtle, but in that code block, if the cache_override is set to any falsey value (e.g., an empty string, 0, or False), the fallback to self._internal_cache won't trigger, and the behavior might not be as intended. To avoid any confusion or unexpected behavior, it's recommended to use an explicit != 0 check or similar condition when handling fallbacks.

column1:
The compiler gets confused about
  base::BindOnce(StoreFiles, {{policy_path, policy_blob}})
 with error message
  ../../base/bind.h:272:25: note: candidate function template not viable: requires single argument 'closure', but 2 arguments were provided

column2: The compiler gets confused when encountering the following line: base::BindOnce(StoreFiles, {{policy_path, policy_blob}}). The error message indicates that it requires a single argument 'closure,' but two arguments were provided. To address this, you can use the following workaround: base::BindOnce(StoreFiles, std::map<base::FilePath, std::string>({{policy_path, policy_blob}})).

column1:
this is horribly inefficient: it copies each parameter twice!
also, when inserting many items, it is _much_much_much_ faster to do setRowCount() and fill in the rows; one also needs to block signals to make it event faster
in the end, if there's so much data that even setRowCount() is slow, split the data into batches and insert using incremental setRowCount()s
now it's ridiculously slow - as Qt reallocates and redraws way too often
column2: This implementation is highly inefficient since it copies each parameter twice. Additionally, when inserting many items, it's much faster to use setRowCount() and fill in the rows. Blocking signals can further improve performance. If there's an excessive amount of data causing even setRowCount() to be slow, it's recommended to split the data into batches and insert them using incremental setRowCount() calls. Qt tends to reallocate and redraw too often, resulting in poor performance.

column1:
it's a write lock, not a read lock.  if you read user.eclass line by line (i know it sucks, but every line in there was fought over and blood spilled), the logic is:

* check if the acct exists; if so, quickly return
* if the acct doesn't exist, grab the lock
* with the lock held, see if the acct still doesn't exist
* add the account *atomically* so that other code exiting (1) above works
column2: This is a write lock, not a read lock. The logic behind reading user.eclass line by line is as follows: (1) Check if the account exists and return quickly if it does. (2) If the account doesn't exist, acquire the lock. (3) While holding the lock, verify if the account still doesn't exist. (4) Atomically add the account to ensure compatibility with code exiting at step (1).

I initially attempted passing in ProcessMemory, thinking it could serve as a base "ProcessMemory" for different platforms. However, I overlooked certain factors: 1) Memory() is a TaskMemory on Mac, 2) MergeWithOtherSnapshotImpl() relies on process_reader_, and 3) Fuchsia doesn't have a Memory() method. While sharing Fuchsia's implementation with Linux's is possible, it would require creating a template and become less preferable due to the header becoming more cluttered. Perhaps we can explore alternative solutions to address this issue.

column1:
Yuck, OK, so this is why we've caught Exception in the past (internally) for ibm-db-sa, the exception you get in the DB2 case is ibm_db_dbi.Warning:
 
 https://code.google.com/p/ibm-db/source/browse/IBM_DB/ibm_db/ibm_db_dbi.py#74
 
 Which just extends the base exception type, none of the sqlalchemy types, which sucks and I should open an issue against ibm-db-sa for this.
 
 So I'd prefer that we:
 
 1. Just remove the try/except for out of tree changes or
 
 2. Use Exception for all backends (even though catching Exception sucks) or
 
 3. Check if the index exists before trying to create it as Johannes suggested.
column2: It seems we have encountered an issue with ibm-db-sa, specifically with the exception type ibm_db_dbi.Warning. This exception extends the base exception type instead of any SQLAlchemy types, which is not ideal. I will raise an issue against ibm-db-sa to address this. In the meantime, we can consider the suggested solutions: 1) removing the try/except for out-of-tree changes, 2) using Exception for all backends (despite its drawbacks), or 3) verifying the index existence before attempting to create it, as suggested by Johannes.

column1:
Let me be clearer:

1/ the legacy behaviour, i.e. the one that the Android libc.so always exposed through its publicly visible atexit() is broken: i.e. the corresponding handlers are never called when a library is unloaded. This may result in resource leaks, but at least no crash. This may result in a crash when the application exits (but _many_ never call exit() and are simply automatically killed by the system).

2/ there *is* existing native code here that is probably buggy but just happens to work due to 1/. And some of this code is never going to be recompiled (if it were, it would be against a newer NDK, and the new code wouldn't have this problem).

3/ Your patch changes the system's behaviour for this legacy code. The end result is not predictable and may results in crashes. We don't want to this chance.

In other words, the risks/benefit ratio for this patch is just too damn high.
column2:
Let me clarify further:

The legacy behavior, which is exposed by the Android libc.so through its publicly visible atexit(), is broken. The corresponding handlers are never called when a library is unloaded, leading to potential resource leaks. Although this may not result in a crash, it can be problematic when the application exits.

There is existing native code that relies on this broken behavior. Some of this code will not be recompiled, as it would require using a newer NDK.

Your patch modifies the system's behavior for this legacy code, introducing unpredictable outcomes and potential crashes. We want to avoid taking this risk.

In other words, the risks outweigh the benefits of applying this patch.

column1:
quantum subnet-create ext_net x.x.x.x/xx --disable-dhcp --allocation-pool start=x.x.x.x,end=x.x.x.x
 
 The allocation pool is important as otherwise it assumes it owns the entire damn thing.
column2:
To create a quantum subnet with the ext_net and a specific IP range, you should use the following command:


quantum subnet-create ext_net x.x.x.x/xx --disable-dhcp --allocation-pool start=x.x.x.x,end=x.x.x.x
Including the allocation pool is essential as it ensures that the IP range is properly assigned.

column1: I completely agree that mocks are very useful, but they should be used with care. If we mock each call that method does and then check that mocks were called - such tests are useless IMO. There was a unit test for this exact case: test_dvr_deletens_if_no_ports_delete_admin_routers which was supposed to catch the regression but it didn't - that's why I call it evil.
column2: I completely understand the value of mocks in testing, but it's important to use them judiciously. Mocking every call and checking if the mocks were called doesn't provide much value in my opinion. I attempted to update the tests in this patch to catch the bug, but I realized they didn't bring any significant value and were hard to understand and maintain. There was a unit test for this specific case, test_dvr_deletens_if_no_ports_delete_admin_routers, which was supposed to catch the regression but failed to do so. That's why I refer to it as "evil."

column1:
Never use complex types / instance as a default values. Because some day you can shit bricks during debug. E.g.
 
  def test(lst=[]):
  lst.append(1)
  print lst
 
 (Try to call it couple of times)
column2:
It's generally not recommended to use complex types or instances as default values because it can lead to unexpected behavior during debugging. For example:

def test(lst=[]):
    lst.append(1)
    print(lst)

# Calling the test function multiple times may result in unexpected output

column1:
> you're following existing style, but existing style sucks

I agree with you on both counts, but at the same time, that's not a battle I'd like to fight with upstream as part of *this* commit.  A mass cleanup of the error handling to use err or similar would be nice, but not in this commit.

As for the uniqueness of the error message, between the error message and the filename, the message should be identifiable, and in any case the error will be identifiable.  In addition, an error other than ENOENT here seems highly unlikely.

Would you consider accepting this patch as-is, please?
column2: I agree with you on both points; the existing style is not ideal, but in this commit, I prefer not to address it. A mass cleanup of error handling to use "err" or similar would be nice but not within the scope of this commit. Regarding the uniqueness of the error message, the combination of the error message and filename should be identifiable, and any error will be recognizable. Additionally, it's highly unlikely to encounter an error other than ENOENT in this case. Could you please consider accepting this patch as-is?

column1:
V[] is not suitable as we need lists of values.
ArrayList<V>[] can't be created in Java and FindBugs tells me than in ArrayList<V>[] values = (ArrayList<V>[]) new Object[size] the cast is incorrect.

In general Java's generics are crap. They are just a compilation time check and arrays support is broken because of inheritance of types.
column2: This implementation using V[] is not suitable as we require lists of values. In Java, it's not possible to create ArrayList<V>[] directly, and the cast in ArrayList<V>[] values = (ArrayList<V>[]) new Object[size] is incorrect. Java's generics can be problematic, especially when it comes to arrays and type inheritance.

column1: What about loop devices, removable devices such as cdroms? They will also be in a list, but do we really want them for installing OS? I'd rather prefer to use the same mechanism as it is in ohai. Ohai parses /sys/block directory, and we can get there a plenty of useful parameters. I want to see if block device is removable or not, if device WR or RO, model name, wwn, ID_PATH, ID_BUS. All those parameters are needed for advanced deployment. For example, I want root fs to be located on a slow shit disk, but I want swap or database partitions to be located on ssd. Maybe we don't need to do this in this particular commit, but we certainly need to have this in our plans.
column2: What about loop devices or removable devices like CD-ROMs? They will also be included in the list, but do we really want them for installing the OS? It might be better to follow the approach used in ohai, where it parses the /sys/block directory and gathers useful parameters such as whether the block device is removable or not, if it's read-write or read-only, model name, wwn, ID_PATH, and ID_BUS. These parameters are necessary for advanced deployment scenarios. While we may not need to implement this in this specific commit, it should be considered for future plans.

column1:
These various ideas all seem to have a built in race condition; I'm not sure which idea is least likely to cause a problem.
 
 For example, if a query for cpu on one of the created servers is done before and after the upgrade, odds are that before the upgrade there will be no results because the pollster has not run. However, that's not _guaranteed_.
 
 Similarly, if a query is done for `instance` it is unlikely, but not impossible, that some data after the upgrade will come from notifications and some from polling.
 
 Therefore I need the answer to two questions:
 
 * How can I form a query that says "only give me polling data for meter X"?
 * How can I form a query that says "only give me results after the upgrade"?
 
 Is there metadata that will allow filters on that?
 
 For the sake on concision and quick resolution pretend a) that I'm an idiot b) the query docs suck.
column2: All the proposed ideas seem to introduce a built-in race condition. It's difficult to determine which approach is the least likely to cause problems. For example, if a query for CPU is made before and after the upgrade, there's a chance that before the upgrade, there will be no results due to the pollster not running yet. However, this isn't guaranteed. Similarly, querying for instance may result in a mix of data from notifications and polling after the upgrade. To address this, I have two questions: 1) How can I form a query to only receive polling data for a specific meter? 2) How can I form a query to only retrieve results after the upgrade? If there's metadata available that allows for filtering based on these conditions, please let me know. Apologies for the lack of clarity in the documentation; I'd appreciate a concise and straightforward resolution, assuming I'm not familiar with the subject matter and the documentation is inadequate.

column1:
i don't think it makes any sense to divide elfutils up like this. it doesn't help anyone. only perf and ltrace use elfutils, and they need most of the libraries.

we're actually fucking this up anyway because libebl tries to dlopen libebl_$(arch), and we're not building those libraries yet. we get away with it because the caller is useless on the target anyway and picks up the OS' libraries on the host! but we should fix that, at which point this probably won't build with clang.
column2: I don't think it's beneficial to divide elfutils in this way. It doesn't provide any significant advantages. Currently, only perf and ltrace utilize elfutils, and they require most of the libraries. Moreover, we seem to be complicating matters because libebl tries to dlopen libebl_$(arch), but those libraries are not built yet. We currently get away with it because the caller is ineffective on the target and picks up the OS's libraries on the host. However, we should address this issue, which might cause problems when building with clang.

column1:
btw, one nasty Android build system gotcha is that all your locals in your makefiles end up in the same namespace. best practice is to prefix everything with your library name to avoid collisions with strangers you don't even know exist. so libchrome_commonCppExtension et cetera.

yeah, it's stupid, and, yeah, the new build system won't have this problem, and, yeah, you usually get away with it, but it's *really* hard to debug when it bites you...
column2: By the way, an important caveat with the Android build system is that all locals in makefiles end up in the same namespace. As a best practice, it is recommended to prefix everything with your library name to avoid collisions with unknown entities. For example, consider using libchrome_commonCppExtension, etc. It may seem unintuitive, and the new build system won't have this issue, but debugging becomes exceptionally difficult when it eventually causes problems.

column2: I am a bit concerned about the implementation here. If the same tag can be associated with multiple resources and the same resource can have multiple tags, this approach may lead to duplicated entries and a non-normalized schema. It would be more efficient to have a separate tag table and a mapping table to handle associations. While this approach requires additional work, it leverages the capabilities of the database management system.

column1:
I am a bit concerned about the implementation here.
 
 If you say that (the same) tag can be associated to multiple resources, and that (the same) resource is associated to multiple tags, this is not the right way to model this logically, otherwise you'll end up having lots of duplicated and a non-normalized schema.
 
 Say for instance that I want to tag my networks with 'golden'. I'd need to have lots of entries like so:
 
  1, golden, 'my golden tag', network, net_1
  2, golden, 'my golden tag', network, net_2
  3, golden, 'my golden tag', network, net_3
  4, golden, 'my golden tag', network, net_4
 
 This is a waste from a number of perspectives: from storage, lookup and cascading effects.
 
 Instead you should have, a tag table
 
  tag, description, where tag is key
 
 and a mapping table
 
  tag_id, resource_type, resource_id
 
 This still sucks though, because now you cannot enforce the foreign key constraint on resource id; i.e. if a resource gets deleted now you gotta enforce the delete on cascade via programming logic, which is yucky.
 
 Ultimately we'd need to have a mapping table for resource. I know, it's more work, but that gives you the most leverage of the DBMS capabilies

@all

The missing_arg_message here seems to be redundant. It would be more informative to print "%s is missing in env and arguments" % some_arg. Additionally, the default_from_global function should handle its own error messages, rather than relying on others to specify what should be printed if the argument is not valid. Another concern is the nested default_from_global calls and their return values. We need to ensure that the return value from default_from_global is valid when used as an argument for another default_from_global call (specifically in L62). Let's address these issues to improve the code's clarity and reliability.

column1: Here add: uniform->dirty = false  You can't clear all dirty bit in uniformArray since you only update the compute uniform constant.  See my another comment in ProgramD3D.cpp

column1: This value is incorrect. This should be the total FS space - free_blocks. You are not including the blocks used for inodes, bitmaps, the superblock and all that crap that comes with the FS. On a FS with all files smaller than 60 bytes, this value will be 0, and that's not what we want. The bug description has the right definition.
column2: The current value provided here is incorrect. It should be the total FS space minus free_blocks, as it doesn't include blocks used for inodes, bitmaps, the superblock, and other FS-related components. The bug description contains the correct definition.

column1:
Every time we do a push to the lab, it calls build_externals to ensure we have the latest chromite/etc.

My concern is user runs this once. Gets chromite.

Down the line repo sync: new autotest changes requires newer chromite.

They run this script again, stale chromite, weird errors, user has no idea wtf went wrong.
column2:
Whenever we push to the lab, it triggers a call to build_externals to ensure we have the latest chromite, etc.

My concern is that if a user runs this script once and obtains chromite, then later during repo sync, when new autotest changes require a newer chromite, they run the script again with the old chromite. This can result in confusing errors, and users won't know what went wrong.

column1:
Ok... to do what you're requesting (use a different name) means we'd wind up with the content in two different vars; or I'd have to split a base class, then derive the git-repo targetting one, then target the manifest-checkout one.  Which would be a pointless pain in the ass.

What was done here works fine, and is sane inheritance/OOP, more importantly, sane pythonic behaviour; '_path' means "the path that this class works on"; it says *nothing* about what that path is, intentionally so, since it's dependent on the class.

I'm not going to change it basically; if you feel strongly enough, -2 it, else register disproval via -1 (if others agree, they'll load up, if they disagree, the 2 and -1 are perfectly fine- won't be offended/annoyed).
column2: Okay, I understand your concern about using a different name. However, making that change would result in having the content stored in two different variables or requiring a significant restructuring of the code. The current implementation works fine, adheres to the principles of inheritance and object-oriented programming, and aligns with Python coding conventions. If you strongly disagree, feel free to express it with a -2 rating or register your disapproval with a -1 (and others can express their opinion as well). There's no need to worry; I won't be offended or annoyed either way.

column1:
And this is why this relation is problematic :) The code here assumes that there is only a single compute_nodes record for the service, which we know is not an accurate assumption, since certain virt drivers can actually have multiple compute_node records for a single host.
 
 So, we actually need to *remove* the compute_node attribute of the nova.objects.Service object, since we should NO LONGER be using the Service object to get compute node information. For the (absolutely shit-brained) os-hypervisors API extension, we will instead want to make separate calls to a new nova.objects.ComputeNode.get_all_by_host() method which will return all the compute node records for a particular host, instead of relying on the above incorrect nova.objects.Service.compute_node attribute.
column2:
And this is precisely why this relation becomes problematic. The code assumes there's only a single compute_nodes record for the service, which we know is not always the case. Certain virtualization drivers can have multiple compute_node records for a single host.

To address this issue, we should remove the compute_node attribute from the nova.objects.Service object. Instead, for the os-hypervisors API extension, we should make separate calls to a new nova.objects.ComputeNode.get_all_by_host() method. This way, we can obtain accurate and reliable compute node information without relying on the incorrect nova.objects.Service.compute_node attribute.

column1:
The "root" in this case isn't actually the root of the dialog, just the root of its content, so a recursive/iterative walk up the chain will go too high.

This is a pretty crappy hack altogether. Maybe some explanation is in order. So, DialogWrapper sets some basic padding for all dialogs in IntelliJ. UX has given us a design doc that asks for slightly different paddings, so I have to walk up the chain and undo the base class padding in order to set our padding later on.
column2: The "root" mentioned here doesn't refer to the root of the entire dialog but rather the root of its content. This implementation involves a somewhat hacky solution. Let me explain: The DialogWrapper sets a basic padding for all dialogs in IntelliJ. However, the UX team has provided a design document that requests slightly different paddings. To achieve the desired padding, I need to traverse up the chain and undo the base class padding before setting our custom padding later on.

column1:
Why are we even doing this header parsing crap btw?

Seems to me this is 1) a time to check/time to run race, 2) we could just handle the appropriate error code w/in the curl fetch, and drop this whole pathway.  3) For alternate urls (aka, .xz which we don't actually support w/in make_chroot), just loop over the fetch function till one succeeds, else dumping complaints for all.
column2: Why are we even bothering with this header parsing process? It seems like a time-consuming check and a potential race condition. Instead, we could handle the appropriate error code within the curl fetch itself and eliminate this entire pathway. Additionally, for alternate URLs (such as .xz, which is not supported within make_chroot), we can iterate over the fetch function until we find a successful one, or report failures for all attempts.

column1:
Hi, neutron 3p CI operator here. We need some way to retrigger on an occasional basis, and a standard syntax would be nice.
 
 Can we come up with a trigger that doesn't contain recheck at all, and just leave that verb to infra to morph as needed?
 
 retrigger/redo/bastard-thirdparty-make-your-shit-work-now-now-now/unicorns-and-rainbows/... ?
 
 Doesn't really matter what.
column2: Hi, I'm the operator for the neutron 3p CI. We need a way to occasionally retrigger the process, and it would be helpful to have a standardized syntax for it. Can we come up with a trigger that doesn't include "recheck" and leave the verb to the infrastructure team to modify as needed? For example, "retrigger," "redo," or even whimsical options like "bastard-thirdparty-make-your-shit-work-now-now-now" or "unicorns-and-rainbows." The actual wording doesn't matter much.

GAE (Google App Engine) is quite problematic. During the init() phase, apps don't have access to their app ID, so I had to resort to using "placeholders" in the pattern strings, as shown in the code snippet. Unfortunately, I couldn't find a cleaner solution. The worst part is that the actual config loading API (cfgclient.Get) doesn't utilize ${appid}, so users must be careful to construct the exact same strings as used in validation patterns. Do you have any suggestions? I'm contemplating moving this "placeholders" concept up a layer to the root of the config library, enabling both cfgclient and validation rules to utilize it. However, it introduces a rather convoluted concept to an already complex API.

column1:
i wonder if there's a cunning hack here for the <string.h> stuff... could we take the upstream-netbsd versions and add them to the libc_netbsd.a but as weak symbols. then anyone who has a platform-specific optimized version can just add the file somewhere else, and we let the linker favor the strong symbols?

that might let us avoid a lot of this makefile crap.

also, i wanted to point out that i'm not trying to say "you must solve my configuration problem for me before i let this change in", which is what my previous comment may have sounded like. for now, feel free to ignore my comments on the makefile; that's just me thinking out loud about where i think we should be going. with intel, mips, and a bunch of different arm vendors all wanting their own optimized <string.h> functions, i don't think this makefile mess scales. it's already unreadable. but we don't have to fix everything all at once.
column2: I wonder if there's a clever hack we can use for the <string.h> situation. Perhaps we can take the upstream-netbsd versions, add them to the libc_netbsd.a library as weak symbols, and allow platforms with their own optimized version to add the file elsewhere. This way, the linker can prioritize the strong symbols, reducing the need for extensive modifications in the makefile. Also, I'd like to clarify that I'm not expecting a resolution to my configuration problem before accepting this change. My previous comment was simply me thinking aloud about the direction I believe we should pursue. Considering that Intel, MIPS, and various ARM vendors all want their own optimized <string.h> functions, the current makefile approach doesn't scale well and is already quite unreadable. However, we don't have to address everything at once.

get_repo_priority=$(shell val=echo $1 | cut -d ',' -f3; echo $${val:-10})

column1:
This is an error-prone approach that is all but guaranteed to bite you on the butt when you aren't looking. What you want to do is filter for allowed characters, rather than filtering out disallowed characters. That is obviously harder to do, but you could do something like:
 
  ALLOWED_CHARS = re.compile(r'[\s\w-]')
 
  if not ALLOWED_CHARS.match(string_to_check):
  raise exception
column2:
This approach is error-prone and likely to cause issues when least expected. It would be better to filter for allowed characters instead of filtering out disallowed ones. Although more challenging, you could consider something like:
ALLOWED_CHARS = re.compile(r'[\s\w-]')

if not ALLOWED_CHARS.match(string_to_check):
raise exception

column1:
Hell no, not this way.

There was a reason the QuickCompiler declaration was hidden from the compiler driver. You're coupling them again.

Introduce another header file with CreateQuickCompiler. Or install the pass managers in the CompilationUnit, so that mir_graph can access them without knowledge of the QuickCompiler (prefer the latter).
column2: This alternative approach is not recommended. There was a deliberate decision to hide the QuickCompiler declaration from the compiler driver, and it would be better not to couple them again. Consider introducing a separate header file with CreateQuickCompiler or installing the pass managers in the CompilationUnit to allow mir_graph access without QuickCompiler knowledge. The latter option is preferable.

column1:
aaarrrgggghhhh ... I guess indent-region won't get this and fix the u-boot formatting. Dammit.

As for u32 vs. unsigned int. I use u32 when it's clearly fixed as to bit width and matches a register directly. But unsigned ints make sense when it's just a value that will get jammed into some bit field. I don't like using fixed-width elements unless it seems mandatory and directly matches some register. I'm doing some interpolation here from the u-boot stuff, and they were not very careful however. I'd like to leave this alone for now. Example: the win_id is 2 bits. There's no good way to express that ("bit fields are a botch" -- signed, the guy who invented them) so I think unsigned int is reasonable.
column2: Argh! This formatting issue persists. I guess the indent-region command won't fix the u-boot formatting. As for the usage of u32 vs. unsigned int, I tend to use u32 when it directly corresponds to a fixed bit width and matches a register. However, unsigned ints make sense when the value will be packed into a bit field. I generally avoid fixed-width elements unless they are necessary and directly correspond to a register. In this case, I'm referring to some interpolation from the u-boot code, which wasn't meticulously done. For example, the win_id is 2 bits, and unsigned int seems reasonable in this context.

column1:
No. Damnit! ;)

Okay, so we are really close now. The only thing I don't like is that we have both RK_CLRSETBITS() and RK_SETMSK() which do the same thing. We should have only one of the two.

Please just:

1. Remove RK_CLRSETBITS() and change everything that uses it to RK_SETMSK()

2. Change to #define RK_SETBITS(val) RK_SETMSK(val, val)

3. Change to #define RK_CLRBITS(val) RK_SETMSK(0, val)

Then we will be fine!

(Alternatively you could remove RK_SETMSK() and replace it with RK_CLRSETBITS(). One or the other, I'm fine with either. Just not both at the same time.)
column2:
Alright, I understand your concerns. Let's work on resolving this issue together. Here's the proposed solution:

We will remove the RK_CLRSETBITS() function and replace it with RK_SETMSK() throughout the codebase.

We'll modify the #define statement as follows: #define RK_SETBITS(val) RK_SETMSK(val, val).

Additionally, we'll adjust the #define statement to: #define RK_CLRBITS(val) RK_SETMSK(0, val).

By implementing these changes, we can ensure consistency and eliminate the duplication of functionality between RK_CLRSETBITS() and RK_SETMSK(). Please let me know if you have any further suggestions or concerns.

column1:
PS: I have used these kinds of sleeps when there is nothing to check, but they are painful, and should be WAY longer than your testing shows is needed in case of heavy system load.

In particular, on a VM on a builder, the load is stupid high, and kernel background threads may not run for 30 minutes or more.
column2: Just a heads up, I've used these types of sleeps in the past when there's nothing to check. However, they can be painful, especially considering heavy system load. We should consider longer durations, taking into account the high load on a VM on a builder, where kernel background threads may not run for 30 minutes or more.

column1:
Even though I'm a moron and forgot that the main purpose of this is to handle private key loss, I think it actually still makes sense to run the mitigator in the case of public key loss as well.  The code is already set up to deal with re-writing the policy blob, and the public half of the key pair is pushed to disk and everything.

We can just have the other code, that would start new key generation to not run in the case that mitigation is happening -- which is easy to detect given a pointer to the mitigator.
column2: Even though I initially overlooked that the main purpose is to handle private key loss, I believe it still makes sense to run the mitigator in the case of public key loss as well. The code is already designed to handle rewriting the policy blob, and the public half of the key pair is pushed to disk. We can easily prevent the other code, which initiates new key generation, from running during mitigation by checking for a pointer to the mitigator.

column1:
Inline ifdefs are very ugly.  Instead, have a dummy function in the header that returns 0 and is a no-op if no "#ifdef CONFIG_QPU_QUIET_STATS".

The compiler will optimize away the "goto" in this case and should even optimize away the extra cpuquiet_unregister_devices(); call...

Similar for other uses of the stats ifdef...
column2: Inline ifdefs are visually unappealing. Instead, let's have a dummy function in the header that returns 0 and is a no-op if there's no "#ifdef CONFIG_QPU_QUIET_STATS." The compiler should optimize away the "goto" in this case and even eliminate the extra cpuquiet_unregister_devices() call. We can apply a similar approach for other uses of the stats ifdef.

column1: yeah, i was going to try to keep this in sysdeps_win32.cpp, but when i looked more closely i realized it wasn't just used for the _win32_lock, it's for *all* the adb mutexes. when we bump the minimum supported version to vista in a week or two, we should be able to fix libc++'s std::mutex and then just delete all this crap. but i agree this is probably the least worst choice in the meantime...
column2: Indeed, I initially intended to keep this code in sysdeps_win32.cpp. However, upon closer examination, I realized that it isn't only used for the _win32_lock but for all adb mutexes. Once we increase the minimum supported version to Vista in a week or two, we should be able to resolve libc++'s std::mutex, allowing us to eliminate this undesirable code. But for the time being, this seems like the best available option.

column1:
nothing. this wasn't actually the problem. the WIN32 was. srhines has a hack in llvm that uses WIN32 rather than _WIN32. one question is: "should we fix that to _WIN32 and remove the hack in the build system?" but a deeper question is "why did srhines need that llvm hack in the first place? is it because we polluted his environment with _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64? in which case, should we stop doing that and just add it explicitly to adb and fastboot?"

(plus: when will 32-bit Windows die so we can get past all this crap?!)
column2: Actually, the problem wasn't related to this particular issue. The real culprit was the WIN32 value. srhines has a hack in llvm that uses WIN32 instead of _WIN32. One question that arises is: "Should we fix this to _WIN32 and remove the hack in the build system?" Furthermore, we need to investigate why srhines needed that llvm hack in the first place. Could it be because we polluted his environment with _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64? If that's the case, should we stop doing that and instead explicitly add it to adb and fastboot? (Also, when will 32-bit Windows cease to exist and free us from all this hassle?!)

column1:
Roughly; pre conversion of cros_build_lib to the logging module, default level was INFO.  When I65a528924 landed, it switched the level to DEBUG (guessing mainly to keep the tests passing) thus dumping a lot of noise into the logs.

In Ic28f1130e I restored it back to INFO via setting the levels via the wrapper, and having cbuildbot up it to DEBUG if --debug is given.  In the process, overlooked the landmine that these tests are dependent on default levels, resulting in it going 'boom' on my ass.
column2: Before the conversion of cros_build_lib to the logging module, the default log level was set to INFO. However, in commit I65a528924, it was changed to DEBUG, presumably to ensure the tests passed smoothly. As a result, a lot of noise was introduced into the logs. In commit Ic28f1130e, I reverted the log level back to INFO by adjusting the levels through the wrapper. Unfortunately, I overlooked the fact that these tests rely on the default levels, which caused issues when running them.

column1:
> I don't think we need to use c-style declarations here, do we?
 
 We don't, but I think the code is more readable this way. Also other code in this file uses c-style declarations. 
 
 > Variables names here are seem to violate the Google style guide, as they're uncommon abbreviations.
 
 I agree that these names suck. But they are consistent with he API that's being used, so I think the code is more readable this way (i.e. calling it io_vector instead of iov wouldn't make this code easier to understand IMO, and I'm not even sure that "iov" means "IO vector" or something else). Also it's consistent with how POSIX APIs are used in this file (e.g. see 'addr' in InternalSendTo()) and how recvmsg() is used in other places in chromium (e.g. see base/posix/unix_domain_socket.cc)
column2: I agree that we don't necessarily need to use C-style declarations here. However, I find that the code is more readable this way. Additionally, other sections of code in this file utilize C-style declarations. While I acknowledge that the variable names could be improved and don't adhere to the Google style guide, they are consistent with the API being used. Renaming io_vector to iov wouldn't significantly enhance the understanding of this code. Moreover, it aligns with the usage of POSIX APIs in this file and the usage of recvmsg() in other parts of Chromium.

column1:

i've raised http://b/19233951 to see if we can do something about this.
column2: For LP64, these variables will be hidden. However, for LP32, we opted to keep them all public for compatibility reasons (although we never thoroughly checked if it was necessary). column1:
because clang is dumb and doesn't provide its own viable libstdc++ implementation. instead, it uses gcc's.

clang is also dumb in that it can't properly lookup gcc internal paths, so we have to do crap like this to work around it.  imo, it'd be better if we fixed clang's internal drivers ... that'll just take more work.
column2: The reason for this workaround is that clang doesn't provide its own viable libstdc++ implementation. Instead, it relies on GCC's implementation. Furthermore, clang has difficulty properly locating GCC's internal paths, which forces us to resort to such workarounds. In my opinion, it would be preferable to fix clang's internal drivers, but that would require additional effort.

column1:
for next time, we did add a comment to the cutils include file:

/*
 * A handful of basic atomic operations.
 * THESE ARE HERE FOR LEGACY REASONS ONLY.  AVOID.
 *
 * PREFERRED ALTERNATIVES:
 * - Use C++/C/pthread locks/mutexes whenever there is not a
 *   convincing reason to do otherwise.  Note that very clever and
 *   complicated, but correct, lock-free code is often slower than
 *   using locks, especially where nontrivial data structures
 *   are involved.
 * - C11 stdatomic.h.
 * - Where supported, C++11 std::atomic<T> .
 *
 * PLEASE STOP READING HERE UNLESS YOU ARE TRYING TO UNDERSTAND
 * OR UPDATE OLD CODE.

sadly we didn't have the balls to add #warning. even ignoring vendor code, there's a *lot* of code using this and its [also] evil libutils twin: https://cs.corp.google.com/#search/&q=include.*utils/atomic.h%20-file:vendor/%20-file:device/&sq=package:%5Eandroid$&type=cs&m=100&sort=1
column2:
For future reference, we added a comment to the cutils include file:

/*

A few basic atomic operations.
THESE ARE HERE FOR LEGACY REASONS ONLY. AVOID.
PREFERRED ALTERNATIVES:
Use C++/C/pthread locks/mutexes unless there's a compelling reason not to. Note that clever and complicated lock-free code is often slower than using locks, especially with nontrivial data structures.
C11 stdatomic.h.
Where supported, C++11 std::atomic<T>.
PLEASE STOP READING HERE UNLESS YOU ARE TRYING TO UNDERSTAND OR UPDATE OLD CODE.
Unfortunately, we didn't have the courage to add a #warning. Even ignoring vendor code, there is a significant amount of code using this and its equally problematic libutils counterpart: [link to code search results]

column1:
Ugh. This is undesirable. We really want Chrome OS upstart jobs to
 depend on a handful of publicly exported events, and "runlevel" isn't
 on that list.
 
 Also, I'm not sure whether this 'stop' condition will guarantee the thing
 we really want, which is that the hwclock sync will complete before we
 shut down.
 
 The best-supported way to do what we want is this:
 
  stop on starting pre-shutdown
 
 That'll cause the post-stop code to run in parallel with stopping
 the 'ui' job, which is what we want.
column2: This situation is not desirable. In Chrome OS upstart jobs, it's preferable for dependencies to rely on a few publicly exported events, and "runlevel" is not included in that list. Additionally, I'm uncertain if the 'stop' condition guarantees that the hwclock sync will complete before the shutdown. The recommended approach is to use "stop on starting pre-shutdown," which allows the post-stop code to run in parallel with stopping the 'ui' job, aligning with our desired outcome.

column2: "NDK" and "user-written JNI" are essentially the same thing. The NDK was shipped with various incorrect type definitions, including sigset_t, off_t, and time_t. While these issues have been fixed in LP64, we cannot rectify them in LP32 without breaking non-platform native code.

column1: Probably not. I spent like a half an hour trying to get those generics to work but Java generics are an awful hack. column2: Probably not. I spent quite some time trying to make those generics work, but Java generics are a rather flawed hack. If you examine the ArrayList implementation, you'll notice that even they use Object[] data to store elements. This limitation stems from the inability to create an array of type V[size] in Java when V is a template parameter.

column1:
funny definition of "shorter". 
Getting the human readable version is done to be consistent with other checks that not only print "bah, your installed version sucks", but also being able to print "we detected that you have version xy installed, but we need at least version wz"

Also your proposal fails short since not all versions of flex report the version as second field. Especially those that are not suitable to build (like 2.5.4 for example) print "flex version <whatever version>":
$ /usr/bin/flex -V | cut -d" " -f2 | sed 's/\.//'g
version

Also while your suggestion works for something like flex (where not much releases are expected), it doesn't account for increase/decrease of the digits in the minor/micro version part

while 2.5.36 will fulfill the test when shortened to 2536 and compared to 2535, a hypothetical version 2.6.1 will be treated as 261 and thus fail the check.

If you only want one single command, and disregard storing the version for printing in the error in case of failure to pass, then one could use 

flex --version |awk '{split($NF,ver,"."); printf("%d%03d%03d", ver[1], ver[2], ver[3])}'

of to be "shorter" :-) : flex -V | awk ....

But That is less readable, and requires doubling of the brackets to satisfy autoconf quoting.
column2: That's an interesting definition of "shorter." The purpose of obtaining the human-readable version is to maintain consistency with other checks. Not only do we print "Your installed version is inadequate," but we can also provide more specific information such as "We detected version xy, but we require at least version wz." The proposal falls short because not all versions of flex report the version as the second field. Additionally, it doesn't account for changes in the minor/micro version digits. While your suggested command may appear shorter, it's less readable and requires extra brackets to satisfy autoconf quoting.

column1:
if any thread is killed in a middle of its operation, the whole app state is completely screwed. We shouldn't even care about such cases (and should never do anything like that)

E.g. if the thread was in a middle of new() call, which locked the memory manager's mutex, and it was shot dead, mutex would remain locked for the whole app forever. Any other library call might do the same thing.
column2: If a thread gets killed during its operation, it can negatively affect the entire app state. Let's avoid scenarios like this and ensure the app remains stable.

column1:
It looks like this is modeled on the incoming call interception...  which, honestly, I hate.  There is no control over how different apps, or visibility for the user into what is going on.  This is one of the reasons this kind of functionality hasn't been introduced yet, because just opening a floodgate of apps stomping on each other in a random order from a broadcast seems likely to leave us in a bad mess.

We've already been here with the media keys, we've got yucky stuff from the outgoing call stuff, let's not do it any more.

I am starting to think that these kinds of facilities deserve some visibility in the settings app, where the user can see what apps are available for the feature, and control which ones are used and their order.
column2: This approach of intercepting incoming calls raises concerns because it lacks control and visibility for users. Let's avoid repeating the same mistakes and consider providing better user control through the settings app.

column1:
Yes. Octal number support is idiotic.

I didn't make a general lint rule to flag this in Java files because lint tends to only check Android-specific issues, not general Java issues (and IntelliJ already has an octal warning if I recall correctly). It seems particularly likely to cause problems here in build.gradle since users are tempted to do things in version codes (see the associated issue)
column2: Octal number support is indeed impractical. Although I didn't introduce a general lint rule to detect this in Java files, as lint primarily targets Android-specific issues rather than general Java problems, it is crucial to exercise caution when using octal values in build.gradle. Additionally, IntelliJ already includes an octal warning, which can be helpful in avoiding such situations.

column1:
This naming sucks.  Better

 for test_specs in test_specs_list

or

 for test_spec in test_specs
column2:
The current naming scheme is not optimal. Consider using one of the following alternatives for improved clarity:

Use the plural form for the variable representing a collection:

for test_specs in test_specs_list:
    # Iterate over test_specs
Use a singular form for each item in the collection:

for test_spec in test_specs:
    # Process each test_spec
Choose the option that best aligns with the semantics and readability of the code.

column1:
CloneGtRepo goes w/in the try block, else there's a race where hit right, it leaves crap behind when it shouldn't.

also, set wipe=True here

Also, you're *so fricking close* to support references here- it's 5 lines or so.

Part of the reason I think you should do it now is that the underlying patch.fetch code is smart enough to skip the network unless necessary; further, if you did patch.fetch(original_repo), your new repo would have the sha1, but the original content would be stored in the referenced repo- meaning no need to fetch again on a subsequent run (aka, if the patching failed).
column2: Place the CloneGtRepo function within the try block to avoid a race condition where it leaves unwanted remnants behind. Additionally, set wipe=True at this point. Furthermore, we are very close to supporting references, requiring just a few additional lines of code. It is worth considering their inclusion, as the underlying patch.fetch functionality intelligently skips unnecessary network requests. By using patch.fetch(original_repo), the new repository would contain the desired SHA1, while the original content would be stored in the referenced repository. This approach eliminates the need for subsequent fetch operations in case the patching process fails.

Furthermore, the use of 0 to indicate success in the C style is rather confusing. Could we modify it to raise an exception in case of an error instead?

column1: Only do this if !data_.empty(). Otherwise, leave only one element in iov. Nobody has promised that data() wont be nullptr if data_ is empty, and if its nullptr, writev() and equivalent dont promise not to blow up, even if the size is 0. Yes, this is stupid. Yes, its a real concern now. Thats why all of the other WriteObject() implementations that youll find are careful to put this iov[1] business in an if (!whatever.empty()) { iov.push_back()); } construct.
column2: We should only proceed with this action if the 'data_' is not empty. Otherwise, we should leave only one element in 'iov'. It is important to note that 'data()' may be a nullptr when 'data_' is empty, and writev() and its equivalents may not handle this situation gracefully, even if the size is 0. Although it may seem illogical, this concern is valid and should be addressed accordingly. Other implementations of 'WriteObject()' take care of this by using an 'if (!whatever.empty()) { iov.push_back(); }' construct.

column1: How do you plan to handle the external references? For example, the following LWN articles has a link this file. And changing the name and/or location will break that link, AFAIK.

column1: IMO symlinks are mostly ending in a mess, URLs are never stable. There is a link to handle such requirements. Take a look at intersphinx to see how it works:  Each Sphinx HTML build creates a file named objects.inv that contains a mapping from object names to URIs relative to the HTML set's root. This means articles from external (like lwn articles) has to be recompiled. Not perfect, but a first solution. I really like them, factually valuable comments .. please express your concern so that we have a chance to move on. I think that's a pity.
column2: In my opinion, symlinks often lead to complications, and URLs are generally not stable. There should be a mechanism in place to handle such requirements. You may want to explore the use of intersphinx, which provides a solution for mapping object names to relative URIs within HTML sets. While it may require recompiling articles from external sources like LWN, it's a step towards addressing this issue.

column1: A version of this patch has been queued by Catalin. Now that the cpufeature bits are queued, I think this can be split up into two separate series for v4.16-rc1, one to tackle NOTIFY_SEI and the associated plumbing. The second for the KVM 'make SError pending' API. I didn't sign-off this patch. If you pick some bits from another version and want to credit someone else you can 'CC:' them or just mention it in the commit-message. Irrelevant-Nit: sys-regs usually have a 'SYS_' prefix, and are in instruction encoding order lower down the file. (These PSTATE PAN things are a bit odd as they were used to generate and instruction before the fancy {read,write}_sysreg() helpers were added). Bits of this are spread between patches 5 and 6. If you put them in the other order this wouldn't happen. (but after a rebase most of this patch should disappear) So this writes an impdef ESR, because its the existing code-path in KVM. And then you overwrite it. Which is a bit odd as there is a helper to do both in one go. How come you don't use this in kvm_arm_set_sei_esr()?
column2:
I appreciate your input, but based on my observations:
Vmalloc is relatively underused.
Allocations don't appear to be excessively large.
There are more significant overheads related to the handling of virtual pages. For instance, the kernel needs to track page tables, perform TLB lookups, and handle page faults. These operations have a greater impact on performance compared to the use of vmalloc.

variable in the spectre code which then influences the sysfs output. And that output should not be "Vulnerable" like you force with the hack above. It actually should tell WHY it is vulnerable despite having had protection in place before the module was loaded.

column1:
Please don't put plain-text files into core-api - that's a directory full
of RST documents.  Your document is 99.9% RST already, better to just
finish the job and tie it into the rest of the kernel docs.


We might as well put the SPDX tag here, it's a new file.


This is all good information, but I'd suggest it belongs more in the 0/n
patch posting than here.  The introduction of *this* document should say what it actually covers. This seems like a relevant and important aspect of the API that shouldn't be buried in the middle of a section talking about random things. So one gets this far, but has no actual idea of how to do these things. Which leads me to wonder: what is this document for?  Who are you expecting to read it? You could improve things a lot by (once again) going to RST and using directives to bring in the kerneldoc comments from the source (which, I note, do exist).  But I'd suggest rethinking this document and its audience.  Most of the people reading it are likely wanting to learn how to *use* this API; I think it would be best to not leave them frustrated.
column2: The decision to deprecate a feature or API is typically based on various factors, including improvements in technology, changes in industry standards, and long-term maintenance considerations. While deprecations may cause initial inconvenience, they often lead to better code quality, performance, and overall system stability in the long run. It's important to adapt to these changes and update your code accordingly to ensure compatibility with newer versions of the software.

column1:
Relatively significant? I do not object to your comment, but in practice i see that:
- vmalloc is used relatively little
- allocations do not seem to be huge
- there seem to be way larger overheads in the handling of virtual pages (see my proposal for the LFS/m summit, about collapsing struct vm_struct and struct vmap_area)
Can you please point me to this function/macro? I don't seem to be able to find it, at least not in 4.15. During hardened user copy permission check, I need to confirm if the memory range that would be exposed to userspace is a legitimate sub-range of a pmalloc allocation. So, I start with the pair (address, size) and I must end up to something I can compare it against. The idea here is to pass through struct_page and then the related vmap area, which already has the information about the specific chunk of virtual memory. I cannot comment on your proposal because I do not know where to find the reference you made, or maybe I do not understand what you mean :sad:

column1: You can't do it this simply as it will cause deadlock due to nested locking of the buf_lock. To share the lock you will need to provide unlocked versions of the read and write functions and use those if the lock has already been taken.
